{{Use Nigerian English|date=April 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox musical artist| <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians --> | name = 2Baba | image = 2face Idibia.png | caption = 2Baba attending the album release party for his sixth studio album, ''[[The Ascension (2face Idibia album)|The Ascension]]''. | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Innocent Ujah Idibia | alias = 2face Idibia | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1975|9|18}} | birth_place = [[Shomolu ]], [[Lagos State]], Nigeria | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] * [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] * [[reggae]] * [[Gospel ]] }} | occupation = {{flatlist| * Singer *songwriter * record producer * entrepreneur }} | years_active = 1994–present
| label = {{flatlist| * [[Hypertek Digital]] }} | associated_acts = {{flatlist| * [[Plantashun Boyz]] * [[Faze (musician)|Faze]] * [[Blackface Naija|Blackface]] * [[Sound Sultan]] * [[Victor Uwaifo]] * [[M.I Abaga|M.I]] * [[Vector (rapper)|Vector]] * [[Wizkid (musician)|Wizkid]] }} |website = [] }}
'''Innocent Ujah Idibia''' (born in [[Shomolu]], [[Lagos State]], [[Nigeria]]), known by his stage name '''2Baba''', is a [[Nigerian]] singer, songwriter, record producer and entrepreneur. Prior to July 2014, he went by the stage name '''2face Idibia'''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Njoku|first1=Benjamin|title=2face changes name to 'Tu-baba'|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2014/07/2face-changes-name-tu-baba/|publisher=Vanguard|accessdate=30 July 2014|date=27 July 2014}}</ref> He is one of the most decorated and successful Afro pop artists in Africa, and is also one of the most bankable artists in Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtviggy.com/lists/know-your-naija-10-nigerian-stars-to-watch/ |title=Know Your Naija: 10 Nigerian Stars To Watch |publisher=MTV Iggy}}</ref>
2Baba has received one [[MTV Europe Music Awards|MTV Europe Music Award]], one [[World Music Awards|World Music Award]], five Headies Awards (Hip-hop award), four [[Channel O Music Video Awards]] and one [[BET Awards|BET award]] for his musical work, four [[MTV Africa Music Awards]], one [[Music of Black Origin Awards|MOBO award]], one [[Kora Awards|KORA award]], and numerous additional nominations.
== Early life == Innocent Idibia was born in [[Jos]], Nigeria . He is from the [[Idoma people|Idoma]] ethnic group in the southern part of [[Benue State]], in central Nigeria.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newswatchngr.com/editorial/prime/bob/10109113755.htm |title=Rise and Rise of Tu-Face |publisher=newswatchngr.com |date=9 January 2006 |accessdate=6 March 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120715031503/http://www.newswatchngr.com/editorial/prime/bob/10109113755.htm |archive-date=15 July 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He attended Mount Saint Gabriel's Secondary School in Makurdi, Benue State. He enrolled at Institute of Management & Technology, [[Enugu]] (IMT), where he did his preliminary National Diploma course in business administration and management. While attending IMT, he performed at school organised shows and parties, as well as other regional schools such as the [[University of Nigeria]] and [[Enugu State University of Science & Technology]]. He eventually dropped out to pursue his music career. While attending IMT, 2face Idibia started composing and singing [[jingles]] at the GB Fan Club at [[Enugu State Broadcasting Services]] (ESBS) in 1996.
Also in 1996, he adopted the stage name "2Face" (Tuface). He cited the reason as "trying to demarcate my personal life with my business life.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fLOjyMuKH20 |title=2Face Idibia Live in London |via=YouTube |accessdate=11 March 2012}}</ref>
== In Plantashun Boiz == He moved to [[Lagos, Nigeria|Lagos]] and started performing with rapper [[Blackface Naija]]. He had met BlackFace while attending IMT.<ref name=Idomaland>{{cite web |url=http://www.idomaland.org/icon/innocent-ujah-idibia-2face |title=Innocent Ujah Idibia (2Face) |publisher=Idomalang.org |accessdate=11 March 2012}}</ref> With Blackface (Ahmedu Augustine Obiabo) and with musician [[Faze (musician)|Faze]] (Chibuzor Oji), he went on to form the trio band [[Plantashun Boiz]].
Plantashun Boiz released two successful albums: ''Body and Soul'' (2000) and ''Sold Out'' (2003)under the Nelson Brown's owned Label (Dove Records)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thenet.ng/2013/06/2face-idibia-working-with-nelson-brown-on-upcoming-album/|title=2face Idibia working with Nelson Brown on upcoming album|author=Editor|work=Nigerian Entertainment Today – Nigeria's Number 1 Entertainment Daily|accessdate=9 March 2015}}</ref> before disbanding in 2004. Relations were marred for many years during which the band broke up and its members started their solo careers. Long after the break-up known as the "Faze vs Tuface" beef, the band came back together in 2007 for the purpose of recording a third and final album entitled ''Plan B'' (2007).<ref name=Idomaland />
==Solo career== After the disbandment of Plantashun Boyz in 2004, all band members sought separate musical careers. 2face Idibia released his debut solo album ''[[Face 2 Face (2face Idibia album)|Face 2 Face]]'' (2004), which established him as a viable solo artist.
Following the release of his debut album, he released his second album ''[[Grass 2 Grace]]'' in 2006, which contained hits "One Love", "True Love, "4 Instance". He is the founder of Hypertek Entertainment.
[[Image:Digital Painting of Idibia displayed at Pop-Up exhibition.jpg|thumb|left|upright|300px|Abstract painting ''Star studded'' of Idibia by designer [[Olufeko]] showcased at a pop-up exhibition themed ENCORE in December 2013]] In 2006, his song "African Queen" was used in the soundtrack for the film ''[[Phat Girlz]]'', which was released internationally.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soundtrackinfo.com/title/phatgirlz.asp |title=Phat Girlz soundtrack |publisher=Soundtrackinfo.com |accessdate=22 May 2010}}</ref>
He released a promotion album in 2008 called ''[[The Unstoppable]]'' releasing the single "Enter the Place". Problems with album distribution in 2007 caused as shift of the release date of the album from 2008 to early 2009. In 2010, 2face released an "international edition" of the same under the title ''[[The Unstoppable International Edition]]'' making him the first Nigerian artist to have an appropriately priced international album.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tribune.com.ng/sat/index.php/entertainment-extra/1108-tuface-checks-piracy-with-classy-album-price.html|title=TuFace Checks Piracy With Classy Album Price|publisher=tribune.com.ng|accessdate=9 March 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130322200436/http://www.tribune.com.ng/sat/index.php/entertainment-extra/1108-tuface-checks-piracy-with-classy-album-price.html|archive-date=22 March 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=Welcome>{{cite web|url=http://www.bellanaija.com/2011/04/28/watch-2face-idibias-bet-international-welcome-to-america-interview-with-lola-ogunnaike |title=2Face Idibia's BET International "Welcome to America" Interview |publisher=Bellanaija.com |date=27 April 2011 |accessdate=7 March 2012}}</ref> 2face released two more singles from the international version of his ''Unstoppable'' album. The international edition of the album won two awards at the 2010 [[Soundcity TV|SoundCity]] Music Video Awards.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenetng.com/2010/11/22/soundcity-music-video-awards-2010-the-winners-circle/ |title=Soundcity Music Video Awards 2010 – The Winner's Circle. |publisher=thenetng.com |date=22 November 2010 |accessdate=9 March 2012}}</ref> He also won the [[Channel O Music Video Awards]] Best African Western award and the [[MTV Africa Music Awards]] for Best Male and Artist of the year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.museke.com/node/7071 |title=Fally Ipupa & Tuface Idibia lead MTV Africa Music Awards winners 2010 |publisher=museke.com |date=12 December 2010 |accessdate=9 April 2012}}</ref>
Upon leaving the music label [[Kennis Music]], he set up his own record label known as Hypertek Entertainment.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nigerianewsdaily.com/nigerianewsentertainment/nigerianewsmusic/12942-tuface-idibia-opens-up-on-the-sucess-story-of-his-hit-track-african-queen--why-he-left-kennis-music.html |title=Tuface Idibia opens up on why he left Kennis music |publisher=Nigerianewsdaily.com |date=28 October 2011 |accessdate=9 March 2012}}</ref> He is part of the Sony All African One8 Project alongside seven other musicians across Africa recording a single with [[R. Kelly]] and [[Prince Lee]] titled "Hands Across the World".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rnbmusicblog.com/hands-across-the-world-video-one8-r-kelly/17936/ |title=Hands Across The World Video – ONE8 with R. Kelly |publisher=Rnbmusicblog.com |date=19 November 2010 |accessdate=9 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120616081256/http://www.rnbmusicblog.com/hands-across-the-world-video-one8-r-kelly/17936/ |archivedate=16 June 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He is the first non-Liberian to become an honorary member of the Liberian music society in recognition for his outstanding contribution to the growth of music in Africa. He has been named Red cross ambassador society of Nigeria. 2face has several collaborations all over the globe, giving his collaborators the opportunity to win an awards for each duet such as street credibility by 9ice, possibility by p-square and lots more. He is adored by his colleagues and every entertainer in Nigeria music industry as a role model. 2face and heavy weight American Rapper Jay Z met in NYC 2014.
2face Idibia has also been an ambassador for quite a number of brands including Guinness, Nigerian Breweries etc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nigeriafilms.com/news/11614/6/endorsement-deals-new-income-source-for-celebritie.html|title=Endorsement deals: New income source for celebrities|author=Nonye Ben-Nwankwo|accessdate=9 March 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141210084933/http://www.nigeriafilms.com/news/11614/6/endorsement-deals-new-income-source-for-celebritie.html|archive-date=10 December 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He is also the brand ambassador for National Agency for Food and Drug Administration and Control.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pmnewsnigeria.com/2011/11/23/2face-idibia-nicks-deals-with-nb-plc/|title=2Face Idibia Nicks Deals With NB Plc – P.M. NEWS Nigeria|accessdate=9 March 2015}}</ref>
==FORTYfied All-Star Tribute Concert== The '''FORTYfied All-Star Tribute Concert''', stylised as '''''#FORTYfied''''', was an all-star [[tribute]] concert organised by 2face Idibia to celebrate his 40th birthday and influence in the [[music of Nigeria]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.thenationonlineng.net/star-celebrates-2face-at-40/ | title=STAR CELEBRATES 2FACE AT 40 | work=[[The Nation (Nigeria)|The Nation]] | date=18 September 2015 | accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref> Hosted by [[Basketmouth]], the [[Nigerian Breweries|STAR Lager Beer]]-sponsored concert was held on 20 September 2015 at the [[Eko Hotel and Suites]] Convention Centre.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2015/09/star-to-celebrate-2face-at-40-with-all-star-tribute-concert/ | title=STAR to Celebrate 2Face at 40 With All-Star Tribute Concert | work=[[Vanguard (Nigeria)|Vanguard]] | date=17 September 2015 | accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref> The concert was attended by dignitaries and featured performances from notable musicians including [[Wizkid (musician)|Wizkid]], [[Burna Boy]], [[Timaya]], [[D'banj]], [[Sound Sultan]], [[Patoranking]], [[Vector (musician)|Vector tha Viper]], [[Wande Coal]] and [[Seyi Shay]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://pulse.ng/buzz/2face-idibia-singer-announces-concert-to-mark-40th-birthday-id4148177.html | title=Singer announces concert to mark 40th birthday | work=Pulse Nigeria | author=Joey Akan | date=8 September 2015 | accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref>
He is also the owner of the Buckwyld and Breathless concert<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vanguardngr.com/2017/09/started-buckwyld-breathless-concert-2face-idibia/|title=Why I started Buckwyld & Breathless concert – 2face Idibia – Vanguard News|date=24 September 2017|work=Vanguard News|access-date=23 January 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life and marriage== 2Face has experienced near-death events, including gunshots from an armed robbery.<ref name=Welcome /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nigeriavillagesquare.com/articles/ahaoma-kanu/tuface-idibia-recuperating-and-fine.-with-exclusive-pict.html |title=Tuface Idibia recuperating and fine |publisher=nigeriavillagesquare.com |date=9 October 2007 |accessdate=9 April 2012}}</ref>
On 2 May 2012, 2Face Idibia and [[Annie Macaulay–Idibia|Annie Macaulay]] married in [[Lagos]], [[Nigeria]] in a private ceremony.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thenetng.com/2012/05/04/2face-Idibia-and-Annie-Macaulay-wed-secretly |title=2face Idibia and Annie Macaulay wed secretly |publisher=thenetng.com |date=4 May 2012 |accessdate=4 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.punchng.com/entertainment/arts-life/annie-anointed-queen-of-a-shooting-star |title=Annie, anointed queen of a shooting star |publisher=punchng.com |date=17 February 2012 |accessdate=3 March 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229124315/http://www.punchng.com/entertainment/arts-life/annie-anointed-queen-of-a-shooting-star/ |archive-date=29 February 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> 2face announced his marriage via his Twitter page. Annie Macaulay and 2Face had their traditional wedding on 8 March 2013 in Eket, Akwa-Ibom State Nigeria. The couple also had a white wedding in Dubai, on Saturday 23 March 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thenet.ng/2013/03/photo-2face-annie-idibia-and-daughter-spotted-at-dubai-wedding/|title=PHOTO: 2face, Annie Idibia and daughter spotted at Dubai wedding|author=Editor|work=Nigerian Entertainment Today – Nigeria's Number 1 Entertainment Daily|accessdate=9 March 2015}}</ref> with Nigerian and Ghanaian celebrities all present to see the long term couple tie the knot.
His wife, Annie Idibia, 17 August 2015, announced that she has opened a beauty salon in Atlanta, Georgia, United States, called BeOlive Hair Studio.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.360nobs.com/2015/08/annie-idibia-opens-hair-saloon-in-atlanta/|title= Annie Idibia Opens Hair Saloon in Atlanta |publisher=360nobs.com |date=18 August 2015 |accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref> 2face has 7 children from 4 different women.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.informationng.com/2015/09/2face-idibia-at-40-meet-the-7-children-of-2face.html|title=2face Idibia at 40: Meet The 7 Children of 2face|last=Deolu|website=INFORMATION NIGERIA|access-date=20 September 2016}}</ref>
== Philanthropy == [[File:Innocent Ujah Idibia and Kafayat Oluwatoyin Shafau.jpg|thumb|Guinness World Record for "Longest Dance Party" Kaffy and Multiple Award Winning Singer 2baba with the Executive Producer of My Funky Birthday TV Nig and ''PadMan Initiative'' Crooner at a reunion to work with this superstar on a Charity Project.]] 2Face has established an NGO called 2Face Idibia Reach-Out Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/video/#/video/international/2011/11/28/inside-africa-2face-idibia-nigeria-a.cnn?iref=allsearch |title='2Face' Idibia: Message behind the music |publisher=CNN |date=29 November 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2012}}</ref> whose motto is "service to humanity".
In 2009, 2Face was appointed as ambassador by [[National Agency for Food and Drug Administration and Control]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2009/09/nafdac-appoints-2face-ambassador/ |title=NAFDAC appoints 2face Ambassador|publisher=vanguardngr.com |date=18 September 2009 |accessdate=9 March 2012}}</ref> He released a song "Man Unkind" to raise awareness on the menace of fake and sub-standard food and drug products in Nigeria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bellanaija.com/2011/04/11/2face-idibia-and-nafdac-tackle-fake-and-sub-standard-food-and-drug-products-in-nigeria-with-man-unkind/ |title=2Face Idibia and NAFDAC tackle fake and sub-standard food and drug products in Nigeria with "Man Unkind"|publisher=Bellanaija.com |date=11 April 2011 |accessdate=9 March 2012}}</ref> In 2009, he was presented with the prestigious International Youth Ambassador for Peace Summit and the Nigeria Youth Merit Award by the National Youth Council of Nigeria in recognition of his contributions to youth development in Nigeria.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nigeriafirst.org/article_8777.shtml |title=Human capital |publisher=Nigeriafirst.org |date=16 April 2009 |accessdate=11 March 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130328054414/http://www.nigeriafirst.org/article_8777.shtml |archive-date=28 March 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Tu Face is presently one of the Judges in The Voice Nigeria, alongside other artists like Timi Dakolo, Patoraking and [[Waje]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://pulse.ng/movies/the-voice-nigeria-2face-idibia-waje-timi-dakolo-patoranking-announced-as-judges-id4577472.html|title="The Voice Nigeria": 2face Idibia, Waje, Timi Dakolo, Patoranking announced as judges|last=Izuzu|first=Chidumga|website=pulse.ng|access-date=21 April 2016}}</ref>

{{pp|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = 2 Chainz | background = solo_singer <!-- includes rappers --> | image = 2 Chainz May 2014 2 (cropped).jpg | caption = 2 Chainz in May 2014 | birth_name = Tauheed Epps | alias = {{hlist|Tity Boi|Drenchgod}} | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1977|09|12}} | birth_place = [[College Park, Georgia]], U.S. | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | occupation = {{flatlist| * Rapper * songwriter * television personality * activist * actor }} | years_active = 1997–present | label = {{flatlist| * [[Def Jam Recordings|Def Jam]] * [[#The Real University|T.R.U.]] }} | associated_acts = <!-- Exercise constraint and add only the NOTABLE acts associated with 2 Chainz; see [[Template:Infobox musical artist#Associated acts]] for criteria --> {{flatlist| * [[Playaz Circle]] * [[Gucci Mane]] * [[Jeezy]] * [[Lil Wayne]] * [[Ludacris]] * [[Migos]] }} | website = {{url|http://www.2chainz.com}} }} '''Tauheed Epps''' (born September 12, 1977),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2012/09/13/video-2-chainz-gets-his-big-booty-birthday-wish/ |title=2 Chainz Gets His Big Booty Birthday Wish |website=Rap-Up.com|accessdate=June 15, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsagents.net/index.php/content/content17/176-2-chainz |title=2 Chainz |website=Sportsagents.net |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref> known professionally as '''2 Chainz''' (formerly '''Tity Boi'''), is an American rapper, songwriter, television personality, activist, and actor. Born and raised in [[College Park, Georgia]], he initially gained recognition for being one-half of the [[Southern hip hop]] duo [[Playaz Circle]], alongside his longtime friend and fellow rapper Earl "Dolla Boy" Conyers. The duo was signed to fellow Georgia-based rapper [[Ludacris]]' [[Disturbing tha Peace]] label, and are best known for their debut single "[[Duffle Bag Boy]]".
In February 2012, Epps signed a solo [[record deal]] with [[Def Jam Recordings]], an imprint of [[Universal Music Group]]. The following August, he released his debut studio album ''[[Based on a T.R.U. Story]]'', to mixed reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/based-on-a-tru-story/2-chainz/critic-reviews |title=Critic Reviews for Based on a T.R.U. Story |website=Metacritic |date= |accessdate=November 20, 2012}}</ref> The album spawned three successful singles: "[[No Lie (2 Chainz song)|No Lie]]," "[[Birthday Song]]," and "[[I'm Different (2 Chainz song)|I'm Different]]", all of which charted in the top 50 of the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and were certified Gold or higher by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]], along with the album being certified Gold. His second studio album ''[[B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time]]'' was released on September 11, 2013. It was supported by the singles "[[Feds Watching]]" and "[[Used 2]]". Mr. Chainz began working with the TV Network [[Viceland]] on a show called [[Most Expensivest]], which debuted its first episode on November 15, 2017, and is currently in its second season.
==Early life and education== 2 Chainz was born '''Tauheed Epps''' in [[College Park, Georgia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/2-chainz-might-run-for-mayor-of-college-park-georgia-2015281|title=2 Chainz Might Run for Mayor of College Park, Georgia: Rapper Gets Political|website=Us Weekly|first=Madeline|last=Boardman|date=January 28, 2015|accessdate=November 8, 2016}}</ref> He attended [[North Clayton High School]], where he played basketball and graduated second in his class.<ref name=beast>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/03/27/2-chainz-is-no-donald-trump-fan.html|title=2 Chainz Is No Donald Trump Fan|website=The Daily Beast|first=Marlow|last=Stern|date=March 27, 2016|accessdate=November 8, 2016}}</ref> While in high school, he dealt [[marijuana]] and was arrested for felony [[cocaine]] possession when he was 15 years old.<ref name=beast/> He later attended [[Alabama State University]] on a scholarship, and played on its basketball team from 1995 to 1997.<ref name="sports-reference">{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cbb/players/tauheed-epps-1.html|title=Tauheed Epps|accessdate=July 4, 2017|work=S-R CBB}}</ref><ref name=espn>{{cite web |url=http://espn.go.com/blog/playbooksounds/post/_/id/3120/how-good-was-2-chainz-at-basketball |website=espn.go.com |publisher=ESPN |title=How good was 2 Chainz at basketball? |accessdate=December 10, 2012}}</ref>
When asked by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' about longstanding rumors that he had graduated from Alabama State with a 4.0 GPA, which had been widely reported on many sources including [[Wikipedia]], 2 Chainz said: "Don't believe anything on Wack-ipedia. There's a lot of false stuff on there, to the point that every time I try to fix one thing, something else comes out."<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/q-a-suddenly-2-chainz-is-everywhere-20120813 | title=Five Reasons Why 2 Chainz Should Make A Presidential Bid | work=The Observer | date=September 25, 2012 | accessdate=January 10, 2016 | author=Vanessa Quilantan}}</ref> In fact, he transferred to [[Virginia State University]] due to circumstances he was reluctant to speak about.<ref name=beast/> "I got into some trouble, went somewhere else, and came back. But I graduated, and that’s that. That was then," he said.<ref name=beast/>
==Career==
===1997–2010: Playaz Circle and Disturbing tha Peace=== Epps formed the hip hop duo [[Playaz Circle]] (the word "Playaz" being a [[bacronym]] for "Preparing Legal Assets for Years from A to Z")<ref name=dubmagazine>{{cite web|title=Playaz Circle|url=http://dubmagazine.com/stars/musicians/410-playaz-circle|work=Dub Magazine|publisher=Dub Publishing |accessdate=May 20, 2012}}</ref> in [[College Park, Georgia]] in 1997, with his high school friend Earl Conyers (known as Dolla Boy), while Epps adopted "Tity Boi" as his [[moniker]].<ref name=allmusicbio>{{cite web |last=Cordor|first=Cyril|title=Playaz Circle – Biography|url=http://allmusic.com/artist/playaz-circle-p733429/biography|work=[[Allmusic]]|publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]]|accessdate=May 20, 2012}}</ref> Following the release of an [[Independent music|independent album]] titled ''United We Stand, United We Fall'' (2002),<ref name=dubmagazine/> the duo were introduced to fellow Atlanta rapper [[Ludacris]], when he moved into their College Park apartment complex, whilst he was acting as a [[disc jockey|DJ]].<ref name=allmusicbio/> After taking interest in Playaz Circle, Ludacris began to record several songs with the group, playing some of them on his [[radio station]].<ref name=dubmagazine/>
Ludacris soon became one of the highest-selling rappers in the [[Southern United States]].<ref name=allmusicbio/> After hearing of their situation, Ludacris requested of Epps that the duo join his newly formed record label [[Disturbing Tha Peace]], a subsidiary of [[Def Jam Recordings]]. Epps agreed to sign, although Conyers did not officially join the label until his mother regained her health, a year after the initial signing.<ref name=allmusicbio/>
Their debut album ''[[Supply & Demand (Playaz Circle album)|Supply & Demand]]'', was released on October 30, 2007. The [[lead single]] and their debut single, "[[Duffle Bag Boy]]", became an urban [[hit single]]. The song features [[Lil Wayne]], and was performed by the duo at the [[BET Hip Hop Awards]]. The duo released their second studio album ''[[Flight 360: The Takeoff]]'', on September 29, 2009. In January 2010, Playaz Circle filmed a music video for their single "Big Dawg" [[featuring]] Lil Wayne and [[Birdman (entertainer)|Birdman]] at Studio Space Atlanta. Shortly afterwards, Epps left Disturbing tha Peace, a move he claimed was taken in order to advance his career. Although Ludacris was initially reluctant to allow Epps to leave the label (as he felt Epps could still prove financially successful), he eventually accepted the decision.<ref name=albumtitle>{{cite web|last=Vasquez|first=Andres|title=2 Chainz Reveals Album Title, Speaks On Leaving Ludacris' Label|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.19019/title.2-chainz-reveals-album-title-speaks-on-leaving-ludacris-label|work=HipHopDX|publisher=Cheri Media Group|accessdate=May 20, 2012|date=March 15, 2012}}</ref>
===2011–12: Name change and ''Based on a T.R.U. Story''=== Throughout Epps's career, critics and fans alike have speculated the [[pseudonym]] "Tity Boi" was meant to be derogatory towards women, although he repeatedly denied such accusations.<ref name=vibenamechange>{{cite web|title=2 Chainz Opens Up About Why He Was Named 'Tity Boi,' T.R.U. Realigion Mixtape, and his Use of Codeine Syrup. 2 Chainz also collaborated with 8 Rochester rapper "Dale Mahoney" on his mixtape "Jordans&Drugs" in 2012.|url=http://www.vibe.com/article/2-chainz-opens-about-why-he-was-named-tity-boi-tru-realigon-mixtape-and-his-use-codeine|work=[[Vibe (magazine)|Vibe]]|publisher=Vibe Media|accessdate=May 20, 2012|date=October 27, 2011}}</ref> In early 2011, Epps decided to change his stage name to '''2 Chainz,''' as he perceived it to be more "family friendly."<ref name=hiphopdxnamechange>{{cite web|last=Harling|first=Danielle|title=2 Chainz Explains His Decision To Drop Tity Boi As A Stage Name, Says 2 Chainz Is More "Family Friendly"|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.18172/title.2-chainz-explains-his-decision-to-drop-tity-boi-as-a-stage-name-says-2-chainz-is-more-family-friendly|work=HipHopDX|publisher=Cheri Media Group|accessdate=May 20, 2012|date=January 3, 2012}}</ref> Following the name change, Epps released a [[mixtape]] entitled ''T.R.U. REALigion,'' which became his first mixtape to appear on the music charts, peaking at number 58 on the US ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums]] chart.<ref>{{cite web|title=2 Chainz – Charts & Awards – ''Billboard'' Albums|url=http://allmusic.com/artist/2-chainz-p2450987/charts-awards|work=Allmusic|publisher=Rovi Corporation|accessdate=May 20, 2012}}</ref> Since the success of the mixtape, Epps has made numerous [[guest appearance]]s on tracks by prominent recording artists such as<ref name=vibenamechange/> Kanye West ("[[Mercy (GOOD Music song)|Mercy]]") and Nicki Minaj ("[[Beez in the Trap]]").
On March 24, 2012, Epps announced his debut [[studio album]], whose title he had changed to ''[[Based on a T.R.U. Story]]'' from its original title of ''T.R.U. to My REALigion,''<ref name=albumtitle/> was set for an August 14, 2012, release date.<ref name=boombox>{{cite web|last=Bark|first=Theo|title=2 Chainz, 'Based on a T.R.U. Story': Rapper Reveals Producers on LP, Speaks on Kanye West|url=http://www.theboombox.com/2012/04/03/2-chainz-kanye-west|work=The Boombox|publisher=[[AOL]]|accessdate=May 20, 2012|date=April 3, 2012}}</ref> The album's lead single, "[[No Lie (2 Chainz song)|No Lie]]," features Canadian rapper [[Drake (entertainer)|Drake]], and was released on May 8, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=No Lie (feat. Drake) – Single by 2 Chainz|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/no-lie-feat.-drake-single/id524552884|work=[[iTunes Store]]|publisher=[[Apple Inc.|Apple]]|accessdate=May 20, 2012}}</ref> On May 11, it was under speculation that Epps had signed to Kanye West's [[GOOD Music]] label, after West [[Twitter|tweeted]]: "2 Chainz is charging 100k for a verse now cause he's G.O.O.D!!!!!"<ref name=twitter>{{cite web |last=West |first=Kanye |title= 2 Chainz is charging 100k for a verse now cause he's G.O.O.D!!!!! |url=https://twitter.com/kanyewest/status/201078576676749312|work=Twitter |publisher=[[Twitter]] |accessdate=May 27, 2012 |date=May 11, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120710080218/http://twitter.com/kanyewest/status/201078576676749312|archivedate=July 10, 2012 }}</ref> However, Epps later denied those rumors, saying: "He just said I’m good, like I’m ill. But we was talking and I think I was jeopardizing my brand sometimes by doing the homeboy special. So I think he felt like we should just put that out there that we ain't doing no more of that."<ref>{{cite web|last=Horowitz |first=Steven J. |title=2 Chainz Responds To G.O.O.D. Music Signing Rumors |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.19725/title.2-chainz-responds-to-good-music-signing-rumors |website=HipHop DX |date=May 12, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Cofr7i3d?url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.19725/title.2-chainz-responds-to-good-music-signing-rumors |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |deadurl=no |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref> On May 30, 2012, [[Ciara]] revealed 2 Chainz was featured on "[[Sweat (Ciara song)|Sweat]]," the intended first single from her fifth studio album, ''[[Jackie (Ciara album)|One Woman Army]].''<ref>{{cite web|title=Ciara Announces New Album ''One Woman Army''|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2012/05/15/ciara-announces-new-album-one-woman-army-first-single-sweat/#more-125650|work=|website=[[Rap-Up]].com |accessdate=May 30, 2012}}</ref>
''Based on a T.R.U. Story'' debuted at number one on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], selling 147,000 copies in its first week.<ref name="Hip Hop Album Sales: The Week Ending 8/19/2012">{{cite web|last=Vazquez|first=Edwin|title=Hip Hop Album Sales: The Week Ending 8/19/2012|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.20875/title.hip-hop-album-sales-the-week-ending-8-19-2012|publisher=Cheri Media Group|accessdate=August 22, 2012}}</ref> The album was met with mixed reviews, earning a score of 55 on [[metacritic]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/based-on-a-tru-story/2-chainz/critic-reviews |title=Critic Reviews for Based on a T.R.U. Story |website=Metacritic |date= |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> As of September 23, 2012, the album has sold 288,000 copies in the United States.<ref name="Hip Hop Album Sales: The Week Ending 9/23/2012">{{cite web|last=Paine|first=Jack|title=Hip Hop Album Sales: The Week Ending 9/23/2012 |website=HipHopDX |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.21300/title.hip-hop-album-sales-the-week-ending-9-23-2012|publisher=Cheri Media Group|accessdate=September 26, 2012}}</ref> In September, Epps performed at the [[2012 MTV Video Music Awards]], alongside longtime friend [[Lil Wayne]]. After the release of his debut, ''Based on a T.R.U. Story,'' Epps made momentous strides. He facilitated his first solo worldwide tour, selling out most of its dates; he was nominated for over 13 [[BET Hip Hop Awards]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Murphy|first=Keith|title=Editor|url=http://v103.cbslocal.com/2012/10/10/kanye-west-2-chainz-kendrick-lamar-among-winners-at-bet-hip-hop-awards/|website=CBS Local}}</ref> bringing home 4 such trophies;<ref>{{cite web |last=Markman |first=Rob |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1695223/kanye-west-2-chainz-bet-hip-hop-awards-winners-list.jhtml |website=mtv.com |publisher=MTV News |title=2012 BET Hip Hop Awards Belong To Kanye West, 2 Chainz |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CofUX5sW?url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1695223/kanye-west-2-chainz-bet-hip-hop-awards-winners-list.jhtml |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref> he earned ''The Source'' Magazine’s "Man of the Year" award;<ref>{{cite web|last=Fitzgerald |first=Trent |url=http://popcrush.com/2-chainz-man-of-the-year-the-source-magazine/ |website=Popcrush |title=2 Chainz Crowned Man Of the Year by The Source Magazine |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Cog88Ltt?url=http://popcrush.com/2-chainz-man-of-the-year-the-source-magazine/ |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref> he released a collaborative endeavor with ADIDAS,<ref>{{cite web|last=Crates |first=Jake |url=http://allhiphop.com/2012/11/21/2-chainz-featured-in-champs-sports-commericials-and-facebook-digital-game-for-adidas-originals/ |website=AllHipHop |title=2 Chainz Featured in Champs Sports Commercials and Facebook Digital Game for Adidas Originals |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CogIrmvk?url=http://allhiphop.com/2012/11/21/2-chainz-featured-in-champs-sports-commericials-and-facebook-digital-game-for-adidas-originals/ |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref> and later Beats By Dre;<ref>{{cite web |last=Kathiya |first=Henna |url=http://rapfix.mtv.com/2012/11/21/2-chainz-azealia-banks-lil-wayne-and-more-star-in-beats-by-dre-ad/ |website=MTV RapFix |title=2 Chainz, Azealia Banks, Lil Wayne And More Star In Beats By Dre Ad |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CogSRorc?url=http://rapfix.mtv.com/2012/11/21/2-chainz-azealia-banks-lil-wayne-and-more-star-in-beats-by-dre-ad/ |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref> and he was nominated for three [[Grammy Awards]], including Best Rap Album.<ref>{{cite web |last=Watson |first=Andrew |url=http://theversed.com/2012/12/10/2-chainz-discusses-grammy-nomination-for-rap-album-of-the-year-thanks-kanye-west-and-drake/ |website=The Versed |title=2 Chainz Discusses Grammy Nomination For Rap Album Of The Year, Thanks Kanye West And Drake |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CogaPVXo?url=http://theversed.com/2012/12/10/2-chainz-discusses-grammy-nomination-for-rap-album-of-the-year-thanks-kanye-west-and-drake/ |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
===2012–15: ''B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time'' and ''Collegrove''=== {{Main|B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time|ColleGrove}} In late 2012, Epps stated once he completed the [[Based on a T.R.U. Story|B.O.A.T.S.]] concert tour, he would reenter the studio. In November 2012, he revealed he was three songs deep into his second studio album. The album's estimated release date was April 2013.<ref name="www.hiphopdx.com">{{cite web | last = | first = | title = 2 Chainz Has Three Songs Recorded For Sophomore LP | url = http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.21735/title.2-chainz-has-three-songs-recorded-for-sophomore-lp | website=HipHopDX | date = | accessdate = November 2, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/features/2013/01/xxl-presents-the-35-most-anticipated-albums-of-2013-3/#18 |title=XXL Presents... The 35 Most Anticipated Albums of 2013 – XXL |work=Xxlmag.com |date=January 14, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> The rapper made a guest appearance on [[NBC]]'s ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]'' in an episode that aired May 8, 2013.<ref name="past">{{cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2013/04/09/law-and-order-svu-season-14-cast-kathryn-erbe/|title=''Law & Order: SVU'' Exclusive: Kathryn Erbe Returns for 'Big' Fin Episode|work=TVLine.com|accessdate=April 9, 2013}}</ref> He also appeared as himself in the second season (episode 16, titled "...And Just Plane Magic") of the [[CBS]] sitcom ''[[2 Broke Girls]],'' where he travels on the same private planes as the two main characters.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.22638/title.2-chainz-guest-stars-on-2-broke-girls- |title=2 Chainz Guest Stars On "2 Broke Girls" |accessdate=May 17, 2013 |website=www.hiphopdx.com}}</ref> On May 23, 2013, he announced that his second studio album ''[[B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time]]'' will be released on September 10, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last=Paine |first=Jake |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.24073/title.2-chainz-announces-sophomore-solo-album-release-date/ |title=2 Chainz "B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time" Release Date, Tracklist & Production Credits | Get The Latest Hip Hop News, Rap News & Hip Hop Album Sales |website=HipHop DX|date=August 22, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> On June 2, 2013, Epps premiered the first single from the album, titled "Feds Watching," at the [[WQHT|Hot 97]]'s Summer Jam. The song featured [[Pharrell Williams]], and it was recorded on 2013 Grammy Awards night.<ref>{{cite web|last=Langhorne |first=Cyrus |url=http://www.sohh.com/2013/06/2_chainz_has_the_feds_watching_at_summer.html |title=2 Chainz Has The "Feds Watching" At Summer Jam [Video |website=Sohh.Com |date=June 3, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vibe.com/article/exclusive-pharrell-making-2-chainz-feds-watching-single |title=Exclusive: Pharrell On the Making Of 2 Chainz 'Feds Watching' Single |website=Vibe |date=June 5, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> On June 15, Epps announced the title of his second album would be ''B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/06/2-chainz-boats-ii-drake-hot-1079-atlanta-birthday-bash |title=2 Chainz B.O.A.T.S. II and Drake at Hot 107.9 Atlanta Birthday Bash |website=Complex |date= |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> The album was released, through Def Jam Recordings, on September 10, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2013/09/2-chainz-pissed-amount-albums-shipped/ |title=2 Chainz Is Pissed At The Amount Of Copies His Album Shipped – XXL |work=Xxlmag.com |date=September 10, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref>
''B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time'' featured [[guest appearance]]s from [[Pharrell Williams]], [[Fergie (singer)|Fergie]], Drake, [[Lil Wayne]], [[Pusha T]], [[Mase]], [[Chrisette Michele]], [[Iamsu!]], [[T-Pain]], Dolla Boy, [[Rich Homie Quan]], and [[Lloyd (singer)|Lloyd]] among others. The album's [[Record production|production]] was handled by [[Diplo]], [[Mike WiLL Made It]], [[Drumma Boy]], [[J.U.S.T.I.C.E. League]], [[Mannie Fresh]], Wonder Arillo, Da Honorable C-Note and [[DJ Toomp]] among others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2013/08/22/tracklisting-2-chainz-boats-2-me-time/ |title=Tracklisting: 2 Chainz – ‘B.O.A.T.S. 2 #MEtime’ |website=Rap-Up.com |date=August 22, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> It was also supported by the single "Used 2," along with the [[promotional single]]s "[[Where U Been? (song)|Where U Been?]]" and "Netflix." Upon the album's release, it was met with generally positive reviews from [[music critic]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/boats-ii-metime/2-chainz |title=B.O.A.T.S. II: #METIME Reviews |website=Metacritic |date= |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> It also faired decently commercially, debuting at number three on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], and number two on the [[Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums]] chart selling 63,000 copies in its first week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5695587/keith-urban-edges-the-weeknd-for-no-1-debut-on-billboard-200 |title=Keith Urban Edges the Weeknd for No. 1 Debut on Billboard 200 |work=Billboard |date=December 1, 2012 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref>
On October 23, 2013, Epps revealed that he had begun working on his third studio album immediately following the release of ''B.O.A.T.S. II''. He also stated he had the first single from his third album ready for release and that he still wanted to get [[Jay-Z]] featured on the album.<ref>{{cite web|author=*Please enter your name. |url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2013/10/2-chainz-working-third-album/ |title=Xxlmag.com |work=Xxlmag.com |date=October 26, 2013 |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref> In November 2015, 2 Chainz revealed that he was releasing a joint album with [[Lil Wayne]], titled ''[[ColleGrove]].''<ref>{{cite web|title = 2 Chainz Announces Next Solo Album & Joint Project With Lil Wayne|url = http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/2-chainz-announces-next-solo-album-and-joint-project-with-lil-wayne-news.18632.html?image=1&gallery=0|website = HotNewHipHop|access-date = February 22, 2016}}</ref> On May 5, 2014, Epps released a brand new EP titled ''FreeBase'' for free digital download. It includes 7 songs, and includes features from [[Lil Boosie]], [[A$AP Rocky]], [[Rick Ross]] and more. The EP has earned over 200,000 downloads.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.datpiff.com/2-Chainz-FreeBase-mixtape.608133.html |title=Datpiff.com |website=Datpiff.com |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref> In January 2014 Epps released a promotional single titled "I'm A Dog."
===2016–present: ''Pretty Girls Like Trap Music'' & Rap Or Go To The League=== {{Main|Pretty Girls Like Trap Music}} On January 27, 2016 Epps released an EP titled "Felt Like Cappin" the EP was released via online streaming sites and [[iTunes]], the EP is promoted by the single "Back On That Bullshit" featuring [[Lil Wayne]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://listen.tidal.com/album/56705198 |title=TIDAL |website=Listen.tidal.com |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref>
Epps began 2016 with the March release of a 12 record collaborative album with rapper [[Lil Wayne]] titled ''[[ColleGrove]]''. The album was supposed to be the debut LP between 2 Chainz and [[Lil Wayne]], however, Wayne’s ongoing lawsuit with [[Cash Money Records]] prevented Wayne from being a primary artist on the album. Epps appears as the primary artist on the album with eight tracks featuring [[Lil Wayne]]. The album features prominent producers such as: [[Honorable C.N.O.T.E.]], [[Mike Will Made It]], [[Zaytoven]], [[TM88]], [[Metro Boomin]], [[London on da Track]], and more. ''[[ColleGrove]]'' received decent reviews from critics and fans.
Epps continued his work in 2016 with the August 5, release of mixtape ''[[Daniel Son; Necklace Don]]'', currently a 9 track mixtape that Epps released independently. ''[[Daniel Son; Necklace Don]]'' originally featured [[Drake (musician)|Drake]] and [[YFN Lucci]] on it but Epps chose to move the song, "Big Amount ft. Drake" to 2017 studio album ''[[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music]]'' due to its mass appeal on the mixtape and star power performance. ''[[Daniel Son; Necklace Don]]'' received a 3 out of 5 stars review from [[XXL (magazine)|XXL Magazine]].
2016 was wrapped up by Epps third mixtape titled ''[[Hibachi for Lunch]]'', released October 28. The seven track mixtape originally featured [[Quavo]], [[Gucci Mane]], [[Ty Dolla Sign]], and [[Future (rapper)|Future]] however, the song, "Good Drank ft. [[Quavo]] and [[Gucci Mane]]" was moved to ''[[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music]]''. Notable production was done by: [[Mike Will Made It]], K Swisha, Buddah Bless.
In 2017 Epps released his fourth studio album titled ''[[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music]]'' on June 16 by [[Def Jam Recordings]]. The album features [[Travis Scott]], [[Nicki Minaj]], [[Swae Lee]], [[Migos]], [[Jhené Aiko|Jhene Aiko]], [[Pharrell Williams]], and more. Album production was done by [[Mike Will Made It]], Buddah Bless, [[Mike Dean (record producer)|Mike Dean]], [[Murda Beatz]], and more. The album was supported by three official [[Single (music)|singles]]: "[[Good Drank]]", "[[It's a Vibe]]" and "4 AM". The album was also supported by a nationwide concert tour, as well as several [[Pop-up retail|pop-up shops]] in the US.<sup>[[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music#cite note-1|[1]]] [[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music#cite note-2|[2]]]</sup> 2 Chainz alluded to the album showing "growth and maturation." He stated the content would maintain its edginess while also elevating [[Trap music (hip hop)|trap music]] to a point where everyone can appreciate it. ''Pretty Girls Like Trap Music'' received widespread critical acclaim, with most critics citing the album as his best album yet.
On November 15, 2017, the first episode of [[Most Expensivest]] aired on the TV network [[Viceland]]. The show focuses on 2 Chainz visiting different locations offering the "most expensivest" goods and services. Each show covers a particular theme, with shows ranging from personal health to extravagant indulgences. The show offers a unique insight into products and services that have been created with the explicit intent on being exclusive and expensive. 2 Chainz offers a unique, and often humorous insight into the products, especially the ones he personally finds to be either amazing or ridiculous. The show has been renewed for a 20-episode third season set to air in early 2019.<ref>https://premieredate.news/tv-series/4568-most-expensivest.html</ref>
[[The Play Don't Care Who Makes It|''The Play Don’t Care Who Makes'']] It is the fourth EP released by Epps on February 8, 2018, by [[Def Jam Recordings]]. The EP consists of four songs one of which features appearances from [[YG (rapper)|YG]] and [[Offset (rapper)|Offset]] on the song "PROUD". Production was done by Minus, June James, Nonstop, Streetrunner, and more.
On February 19, 2018 Epps announced his new album Rap Or Go To The League which is set to be released in 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8208245/2-chainz-announces-new-album-rap-or-go-to-the-league|title=2 Chainz Announces New Album 'Rap or Go to the League'|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref>
==Personal life==
===Family=== Epps has two daughters, Heaven and Harmony.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.papermag.com/2015/05/2_chainz_legalization_voting_rights_fatherhood.php |title=2 Chainz Talks Legalization, Voting Rights & Fatherhood |website=Papermag |date=May 4, 2015 |accessdate=July 24, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://hiphopdx.com/news/id.25929/title.2-chainz-reveals-whether-he-lets-his-children-listen-to-his-music |title=2 Chainz Reveals Whether He Lets His Children Listen To His Music |website=HipHop DX |date=October 22, 2013 |accessdate=July 24, 2015}}</ref> On October 14, 2015, 2 Chainz welcomed his third child, a baby boy named Halo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ballerstatus.com/2015/10/15/2-chainz-welcomes-third-child-a-baby-boy/ |title=2 Chainz Welcomes Third Child: A Baby Boy |website=BallerStatus.com |date=October 15, 2015}}</ref> On August 18, 2018, Epps married his longtime girlfriend and mother of his three children: Kesha Ward.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Pasquini |first1=Maria |title=2 Chainz Marries Longtime Love Kesha Ward in Miami Ceremony (with the Wests in Attendance!) |url=https://people.com/music/2-chainz-marries-kesha-ward/ |website=People |accessdate=28 August 2018 |date=August 18, 2018}}</ref>
===Legal issues=== At the age of 15, Epps was convicted of [[felony]] [[cocaine]] possession.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/07/2-chainz-breakfast-club-interview |title=2 Chainz Breakfast Club Interview |website=Complex |date=July 25, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> On February 14, 2013, Epps was arrested in [[Maryland]] en route to a concert at [[University of Maryland Eastern Shore|UMES]] for [[Cannabis (drug)|marijuana]] possession. Epps was then cited and released.<ref>{{cite news|title=2 Chainz Arrested in Maryland on Marijuana Charge|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/2-chainz-arrested-in-maryland-on-marijuana-charge-20130215|newspaper=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=February 15, 2013<!-- 1:35 PM-->}}</ref>
On June 11, 2013, Epps was arrested while on board a departing flight at [[LAX]] airport for possession of a controlled substance after TSA agents found that his checked bag contained [[marijuana]] and [[promethazine]]. He was booked and charged with [[felony]] narcotics possession. Later that day he posted $10,000 bond and was released. He was due back in court on June 21, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2013/06/2-chainz-arrested-in-lax-for-possession-of-marijuana-and-promethazine/ |title=2 Chainz Arrested In LAX For Possession Of Marijuana And Promethazine – XXL |work=Xxlmag.com |date=June 11, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> Two days previous, he was reportedly robbed at gunpoint outside a [[medical marijuana]] dispensary in [[San Francisco]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Rapper 2 Chainz robbed outside S.F. marijuana dispensary|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/crime/2013/06/10/rapper-2-chainz-robbed-outside-s-f-marijuana-dispensary/|agency=Associated Press|website=SFGate.com|accessdate=June 27, 2013|date=June 10, 2013}}</ref>
Just before midnight on August 21, 2013, Epps' tour bus was pulled over in [[Oklahoma City|Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]], because the passenger side taillights were out. The arresting officer reported that he smelled marijuana and saw smoke through the open door of the bus after he had stopped and pulled over the bus. The driver of the bus shut the door and told officers he was not authorized to allow them on the bus. The officer said the [[marijuana]] smell gave him probable cause to search, but the driver refused to open the door. After many attempts to enter, the bus was towed with the men still aboard to the police training center in Oklahoma City. Officers obtained a search warrant and the 10 men, including Epps, got off the bus. Police discovered two semi-automatic pistols and a 12-gauge pump shotgun, along with some prescription painkillers and marijuana residue, on the tour bus according to papers filed [[Oklahoma County, Oklahoma|Oklahoma County]] district Court.<ref>{{cite web|author=MICHAEL MCNUTT mmcnutt@opubco.com • |url=http://newsok.com/oklahoma-city-police-found-weapons-painkillers-on-rappers-tour-bus-court-papers-show/article/3878935 |title=Oklahoma City police found weapons, painkillers on rapper's tour bus, court papers show |website=News OK |date=September 3, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref>
==Business ventures==
In October 2016, he opened a line of hoodies called CEO Millionaires or Create Every Opportunity Millionaires.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/2-chainz-releases-new-line-of-ceo-millionaires-hoodies-news.24735.html? |title=2 Chainz releases line of hoodies |last=Goddard |first=Kevin |date=October 14, 2016 |website=[[Hotnewhiphop]] |access-date=October 14, 2016}}</ref> He also has his own line of sweaters called "Dabbing Sweaters."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/2-chainz-reveals-new-line-of-dabbing-santa-sweaters-news.25560.html? |title=2 Chainz releases line of sweaters called "Dabbin Sweaters"|last=Goddard |first=Kevin |date=November 19, 2016 |website=[[Hotnewhiphop]] |access-date=November 19, 2016}}</ref>

II: Me Time]]'' (2013) * ''[[ColleGrove]]'' (2016) * ''[[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music]]'' (2017) * ''Rap or Go to the League'' (2018)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2018/02/2-chainz-announces-next-album-rap-or-go-to-the-league|title=2 Chainz Announces His Next Album 'Rap or Go to the League'|work=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]|last=Elder|first=Sajae|date=February 17, 2018|accessdate=February 18, 2018}}</ref>
==The Real University== {{Infobox record label | name = The Real University | image = | image_size = | Also Known As = T.R.U., The Real U | founded = 2015 | founder = 2 Chainz (CEO) | status = Active | distributor = | country = United States | location = Atlanta, Georgia | url = }}
On January 6, 2015, 2 Chainz announced that he was starting his own independent record label "The Real University" (also known as "T.R.U."; or "The Real U").<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thesource.com/2015/01/06/2-chainz-announces-the-real-university-label-with-mix-tape-tru-jack-city/ |title=2 Chainz Announces The Real University Label With Mix-tape "Tru Jack City" |website=The Source |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=*Please enter your name. |url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/new-music/2015/01/2-chainz-featuring-cap-1-young-dolph-trap-house-stalkin/ |title=2 Chainz Featuring Cap 1 And Young Dolph "Trap House Stalkin" – XXL |work=Xxlmag.com |date=January 6, 2015 |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref> The announcement also revealed that frequent collaborators Cap.1 & Skooly were signed. Additionally, they signed former [[Young Money]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youngmoneyhq.com/artists/short-dawg/ |title=Short Dawg | Young Money Artist |website=Youngmoneyhq.com |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=<!-- author name --> Amir Diamond <!-- post timestamp --> |url=http://theboxhouston.com/9521719/find-out-why-short-dawg-aka-freh-is-no-longer-with-young-money/ |title=Find Out Why Short Dawg aka Fre$h Is No Longer With Young Money!! | 97.9 The Box |website=Theboxhouston.com |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref> artist Short Dawg, who is now known as Fresh. Along with the announcement of the label's founding, they also revealed they'd be releasing their debut mixtape ''TRU Jack City'' on January 27, 2015.

{{Infobox musical artist |name = 40 |background = non_performing_personnel |image = |caption = |birth_name = Noah James Shebib |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1983|03|31}} |birth_place =[[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada |genre = {{hlist|[[Hip hop music|Hip hop]]|[[Contemporary R&B|R&B]]}} |occupation = {{hlist|[[Record producer]]|[[songwriter]]|[[child actor]]}} |years_active = 1996–present |label = {{hlist|[[OVO Sound]]|[[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]]}} |associated_acts = {{hlist|[[Drake (musician)|Drake]]|[[PartyNextDoor]]|[[P Reign]]|[[Majid Jordan]]|[[Alicia Keys]]|[[The Weeknd]]}} }} '''Noah James Shebib''' (born March 31, 1983), better known as '''40''', is a Canadian [[record producer]] and former [[child actor]] from [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]]. He is best known for his musical collaborations with Canadian rapper [[Drake (musician)|Drake]]; he has produced all of Drake's albums. Shebib's style of production, which is often down-tempo and ambient, has become heavily associated with Drake's music. Shebib and Drake are two of the three co-founders of the [[OVO Sound]] label. Shebib has also produced for artists including [[Lil Wayne]], [[Alicia Keys]], [[Action Bronson]], and [[Jamie Foxx]]. ==Early life== Noah James Shebib is the son of director [[Donald Shebib]] and actress [[Tedde Moore]], who is known for appearing in the 1983 film ''[[A Christmas Story]]''; she was pregnant with him during the production of that film. On his mother's side, he is the grandson of actor and educator [[Mavor Moore]], the great-grandson of Canadian theatre figure [[Dora Mavor Moore]], and the great-great-grandson of Scottish-born economist [[James Mavor]].https://www.cbc.ca/radio/tapestry/the-redemptive-power-of-hip-hop-1.4752075/ovo-producer-noah-40-shebib-and-his-sister-suzanna-empower-youth-through-hip-hop-1.4752159 His father is of [[Lebanese people|Lebanese]] and [[Irish people|Irish]] descent.https://www.soundonsound.com/techniques/noah-40-shebib-recording-drakes-headlines{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2011/11/interview-noah-40-shebib-talks-take-care-drake/page/2|title=Interview: Noah "40" Shebib Talks Drake, "Take Care," and The History of Toronto Hip-Hop|publisher=|accessdate=1 July 2016}} He has one sibling, a younger sister, Anna Oniell. ==Acting career== Shebib began as a [[child actor]], playing roles in television shows and films. His first role was in the 1996 "Go Eat Worms" episode of the ''[[Goosebumps (TV series)|Goosebumps]]'' television series. He also played a consistent role on the [[Gemini Award]]-winning television series, ''[[Wind at My Back]]''. His best-known role came in his teen years, when he was featured as one of the lead males in the critically acclaimed ''[[The Virgin Suicides (film)|The Virgin Suicides]]''. He also had smaller roles in ''[[The Last Don]]'' and ''[[Perfect Pie]]''; the latter was his last movie before he retired from acting.[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0790520/ Noah's acting career] "IMDB". Accessed on April 7, 2010.[http://www.complexmag.ca/music/2010/06/the-acting-career-of-drakes-producer-noah-40-shebib/goosebumps The Acting Career of Drake's Producer Noah "40" Shebib] "Complex". Accessed on August 14, 2013 ==Music career== Early in Noah's career, before he started crafting beats, he DJ'd under the name DJ Decibel and performed alongside MC Elite (Everett MacLean). Shebib eventually made the shift from DJ to music producer, working with local Toronto artists like Empire, Knamelis, Stolenowners, and Christopher Morales, and Saukrates. He earned the nickname "40 Days & 40 Nights" (which was later reduced to "40") early on in his career, as he would work in the studio throughout the night, with no sleep. He began working with then ''[[Degrassi: The Next Generation|Degrassi]]'' star [[Drake (musician)|Aubrey Graham]] (Drake) in 2005. He was shown producing with Drake on ''Degrassi Unscripted''. When Shebib first started working with Drake, he was originally just a recording and mixing engineer, providing no songwriting or production input at all. However, after the third day of work, Shebib decided to build an exclusive relationship with Drake, proclaiming that they were "going to take over the world together." Shebib's big break came in 2009, when he [[executive producer|executive produced]] Drake's mixtape ''[[So Far Gone (mixtape)|So Far Gone]]'' with Toronto-based producer, [[Boi-1da]]. He recorded and mixed every song off the mixtape, and also produced a few notable tracks such as "The Calm", "Houstatlantavegas", "Bria's Interlude" and "[[Successful (song)|Successful]]", all of which ended up defining Drake's sound going forward.[https://www.gq.com/entertainment/music/201111/noah-shebib-40-drake-take-care-producer Noah "40" Shebib interview on Take Care by Drake]. "GQ". Accessed on August 14, 2013. He also worked on Drake's debut album ''[[Thank Me Later]]'', and second album ''[[Take Care (album)|Take Care]]''.[http://www.allmusic.com/artist/noah-shebib-mn0001088755/credits Noah Shebib Credits]. "AllMusic". August 14, 2013. On the latter, Shebib co produced almost every song, alongside his usual duties of recording and mixing the entire album.[http://hiphop-n-more.com/2011/11/drake-take-care-booklet-production-credits/ Drake - Take Care Album Credits] "Hip Hop n More". Accessed on August 14, 2013. Shebib also produced the song "I'm Single" from [[Lil Wayne]]'s "[[No Ceilings]]" mixtape, "[[Un-Thinkable (I'm Ready)]]" for [[Alicia Keys]] and "[[Demonstrate (song)|Demonstrate]]" for [[JoJo (singer)|JoJo]]. Shebib, along with Drake and Oliver El-Khatib, founded the [[October's Very Own|OVO]] record label in 2012. Music produced under the imprint is uploaded to the label's blog site for streaming, before the album is officially released.[http://octobersveryown.blogspot.ca/ OVO Blog] "October's Very Own". Accessed on August 14, 2013. One example is the single "[[Marvins Room]]", which was first posted to the blog site five days after its conception, before it was even slated to be a single off the album. Recently Shebib has helped produce Drake's newer material, co producing the lead single "[[Started from the Bottom]]", among other records.{{cite web|last=TBTENTGROUP|title=Noah "40" Shebib talks "Started from the Bottom" and Drake's new album with Hollywood Reporter|url=http://www.hip-hopvibe.com/2013/02/07/noah-40-shebib-talks-started-from-the-bottom-and-drakes-new-album-with-hollywood-reporter/|publisher=Hip Hop Vibe|accessdate=25 March 2013}} Shebib also worked on Drake's third album, ''[[Nothing Was the Same]]'',[http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/earshot/drake-dream-team-how-noah-418975 The Drake Dream Team]. "The Hollywood Reporter". Accessed on August 14, 2013.[http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2013/08/02/drakes-new-album-nothing-was-the-same_n_3691516.html#slide=2765350 Drake's New Album]. "The Huffington Post". Accessed on August 14, 2013. his 2015 surprise release mixtape ''[[If You're Reading This It's Too Late]]''[https://genius.com/Drake-if-youre-reading-this-its-too-late-credits-lyrics Drake - If You're Reading This It's Too Late Credits]. "(rap)genius.com". Accessed on March 22, 2015. and his fourth studio album ''[[Views (album)|Views]]''. ==Production style== Shebib has been instrumental in creating [[Drake (rapper)|Drake]]'s music, and together their "atmospheric, brooding sound has revitalised hip-hop."[http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/mar12/articles/it-0312.htm Noah '40' Shebib: Recording Drake's 'Headlines'] "Sound On Sound". Accessed on August 14, 2013. Shebib's production is described as "sparse, ambient, slow-jam-like tracks dominated by brooding synths, minimalist piano or guitar parts, stripped-down, often muffled drums, and cinematic atmospheric treatments." An example is the song "[[Marvins Room]]", where Shebib mixed the record so that it is "very dark and quiet and muddy and with the vocals cutting through like a razor" and is notorious for being heavy on the low end. ==Personal life== In 2005, at the age of 22, Shebib was diagnosed with [[multiple sclerosis]].{{cite web|url=http://thechart.blogs.cnn.com/2012/04/17/the-beat-goes-on-for-music-producer-diagnosed-with-multiple-sclerosis/?hpt=hp_c3|title=The beat goes on for music producer diagnosed with multiple sclerosis|publisher=CNN|author=Tinker, Ben|date=2012-04-17|accessdate=2012-04-17}}[http://www.nationalmssociety.org/Living-Well-With-MS/Personal-Stories/Ambassadors-Familiar-Faces/Noah-40-Shebib Noah "40" Shebib: The rap on MS] "National MS Society". Accessed on August 14, 2013. His personal story is prominently featured on the [[National Multiple Sclerosis Society]] website, where he outlines his experiences with the disease, hoping that by creating awareness and "improving connections and knowledge about MS, we can end the disease". His mother was also diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. ==Discography== {{Main|Noah "40" Shebib production discography}} ===Singles produced=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |+ List of singles as either producer or co-producer, with selected chart positions and certifications, showing year released, performing artists and album name ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:16em;" | Title ! scope="col" rowspan="2" | Year ! scope="col" colspan="10" | Peak chart positions ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:12em;" | [[List of music recording certifications|Certifications]] ! scope="col" rowspan="2" | Album |- ! scope="col" style="width:3em;font-size:90%;" | [[Billboard Hot 100|US]]

{{short description|American record producer}} {{for|the comic-book series based on the [[Heroes (U.S. TV series)|Heroes]] television series|9th Wonders!}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians --> | name = 9th Wonder | image = 9thWonderAtPaidDues-2008-resized.jpg | caption = 9th Wonder in 2008. | background = non_performing_personnel <!-- mandatory format: please do not change or remove --> | birth_name = Patrick Denard Douthit | alias = 9th Wonder, 9thmatic | birth_date = {{Birth date and age |mf=yes|1975|01|15}} | birth_place = [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina|Winston-Salem]], North Carolina | instrument = [[Akai MPC]] 2500, [[Phonograph|Turntables]], [[Pro Tools]], [[FL Studio]], [[Maschine]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.xlr8r.com/features/2008/05/9th-wonder-studio |title=In the Studio: 9th Wonder |publisher=XLR8R |date=May 29, 2008 |accessdate=May 12, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110701120307/http://www.xlr8r.com/features/2008/05/9th-wonder-studio |archivedate=July 1, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | occupation = [[Record producer]], [[Music executive|record executive]], [[rapper]] | years_active = 1997–present | label = [[It's a Wonderful World Music Group]] | associated_acts = [[Little Brother (group)|Little Brother]], [[Murs (rapper)|Murs]], [[David Banner]], [[Buckshot (rapper)|Buckshot]], [[Erykah Badu]] }} '''Patrick Denard Douthit'''<ref>{{cite web|title=9th Wonder Bio|url=http://www.9thwonder.com/9th-wonder-bio.html|website=9thwonder.com|accessdate=2015-10-28}}</ref> (born January 15, 1975),<ref name="MuzeBio">[http://www.nme.com/artists/9th-wonder ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414063729/http://www.nme.com/artists/9th-wonder |date=April 14, 2009 }}</ref> better known as '''9th Wonder''', is a [[hip hop music|hip hop]] record producer, [[record executive]], [[DJ]], [[lecturer]], and [[Rapping|rapper]] from [[Midway, North Carolina]], U.S. He began his career as the main producer for the group [[Little Brother (group)|Little Brother]] in [[Durham, North Carolina]], and has also worked with [[Mary J. Blige]], [[Jean Grae]], [[Wale (rapper)|Wale]], [[Jay-Z]], [[Murs (rapper)|Murs]], [[Drake (entertainer)|Drake]], [[Buckshot (rapper)|Buckshot]], [[Chris Brown (American entertainer)|Chris Brown]], [[Destiny's Child]], [[J. Cole]], [[Kendrick Lamar]], [[Erykah Badu]], [[Ludacris]], [[Mac Miller]], [[David Banner]], [[Lecrae]], [[Jill Scott]], [[Big Boi]], [[Rapsody]], and [[Anderson .Paak]]. As of 2010, 9th Wonder raps under the name of 9thmatic.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tullis |first=Eric |url=http://www.indyweek.com/scan/archives/2010/01/07/fraggle-naggle-meet-9thmatic-the-rapper |title=Fraggle Naggle: Meet 9thmatic, the rapper | Scan | Independent Weekly |publisher=Indyweek.com |date=January 7, 2010 |accessdate=September 8, 2010}}</ref> 9th Wonder has a smooth and soulful production style that builds on samples from artists such as [[Al Green]] and [[Curtis Mayfield]].<ref name="remixmag.com">{{cite web |url=http://emusician.com/remixmag/artists_interviews/musicians/remix_little_feat/ |title=An interview with 9th Wonder – producer 9th Wonder on working with Jay-Z and his group Little Brother |publisher=Remixmag.com |accessdate=January 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101113060632/http://emusician.com/remixmag/artists_interviews/musicians/remix_little_feat/ |archivedate=November 13, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Music career== 9th Wonder's first significant career breakthrough came in 2003 when, as an up-and-coming producer, he released an unofficial remix album of [[Nas (rapper)|Nas]]' 2002 album ''[[God's Son (album)|God's Son]]'' entitled ''[[God's Stepson]]''.<ref name="hitquarters.com"/> Released through internet outlets, the album garnered significant attention and acclaim.<ref name="hitquarters.com"/> The producer has said that he was not thinking in terms of using it to generate a buzz or promote his skills at that point: "I never thought any of this of me as a producer was going to happen."<ref name="hitquarters.com"/> The album has since been credited as starting the now regular trend for unofficial 'home-made' remixes of whole albums.<ref name="hitquarters.com"/>
9th Wonder began his career as the main producer for the group [[Little Brother (group)|Little Brother]]. As part of Little Brother he gained recognition and critical acclaim for his production on their debut 2003 release, ''[[The Listening (Little Brother album)|The Listening]]''. [[Jay-Z]]'s studio engineer Young Guru was impressed with his work, and contacted 9th Wonder, which led to 9th Wonder producing "Threat" for Jay-Z's 2003 ''[[The Black Album (Jay-Z album)|The Black Album]]''.<ref name="hitquarters.com"/> The cut proved to be a mainstream breakthrough for 9th Wonder, most immediately in the major production role he secured on Destiny's Child's 2004 ''[[Destiny Fulfilled]]'' album that Jay-Z was instrumental in helping bring about.<ref name="hitquarters.com"/> On the album, 9th Wonder produced the tracks "[[Girl (Destiny's Child song)|Girl]]" and "Is She the Reason," plus the bonus track "Game Over".
9th Wonder left Little Brother in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hiphopgame.com/news.php3?id=1510 |title=Hip Hop News Audio, News, Videos, Albums, Ringtones, Lyrics, Urban Wear |publisher=HipHopGame.com |date=January 27, 2007 |accessdate=May 12, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Listen to More: Producer, Underground |url=http://www.djbooth.net/index/interviews/entry/9th-wonder-interview-1011071/ |title=9th Wonder Interview |publisher=Djbooth.net |date=October 10, 2007 |accessdate=May 12, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613162350/http://www.djbooth.net/index/interviews/entry/9th-wonder-interview-1011071/ |archivedate=June 13, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On October 29, 2007, 9th Wonder made a rare public appearance on [[Black Entertainment Television|BET]]'s ''[[Rap City (BET program)|Rap City]]'', alongside collaborator [[Talib Kweli]]. [[Madlib]], [[Jean Grae]] and [[Erykah Badu]] appeared as well. In 2010, he appeared on BET's ''[[106 & Park]]'' countdown with [[David Banner]].
9th Wonder, E. Jones, and rapper [[J. Cole]] served as the lead producers of the soundtrack to the [[EA Sports]] video game ''[[NBA Elite 11]]''. 9th Wonder and J. Cole also appear as "secret characters" in ''[[NBA Jam (2010 video game)|NBA Jam]]'' with a team name of Cole & Wonder.
9th Wonder debuted his rapping alter-ego 9thmatic in late 2009. 9thmatic appeared on songs with [[Khrysis]] and [[Sean Boog]], Big Remo, [[Murs (rapper)|Murs]] and Thee Tom Hardy.
9th Wonder worked with Mississippi rapper [[David Banner]] on a collaborative album entitled ''[[Death of a Pop Star]]'' which was released on December 21, 2010. After forming Jamla Records in 2010, he then went on produce for Jill Scott, Dilated Peoples, Big Boi of Outkast, and Anderson .Paak.
==It's a Wonderful World Music Group== In January 2009, 9th Wonder announced plans to start two independent record labels, Jamla and The Academy, under his imprint [[It's A Wonderful World Music Group]] (IWWMG). Jamla originally consisted of [[Skyzoo]], GQ, [[Rapsody]], Tyler Woods and Big Remo, while The Academy consisted of Thee Tom Hardy, Actual Proof (Sundown & Enigma), TP, and [[The Away Team (group)|The Away Team]] ([[Khrysis]] & [[Sean Boog]]). The Academy artists were later folded into the Jamla label. Halo and Heather Victoria were announced as the newest members of IWWMG in October 2010. Jamla Records now consists of artists GQ, Rapsody, Actual Proof, TP, Halo, & Heather Victoria.
In July 2004 a.d., 9th Wonder officially debuted his production team for IWWMG. The Soul Council consists of [[Khrysis]], E. Jones, Ka$h Don't Make Beats, AMP, Eric G., Nottz, Hi-Tek and 9th Wonder himself.
==Recent and current projects== In 2010, independent filmmaker Kenneth Price documented 9th Wonder's travels for an entire year. This included his times in the studio, classes he taught at [[Duke University]], and performances with Murs at the [[Rock the Bells#2010 Festival Series|2010 Rock the Bells Festival]], along with interviews with 9th Wonder about his life and career. All of this was compiled in a [[Lifted Research Group]]-sponsored documentary film titled ''The Wonder Year''. The film features appearances by [[Drake (entertainer)|Drake]], DJ Premier, [[DJ Green Lantern]], J. Cole, Murs, Lucas Rivers, [[Sha Money XL]], Young Guru, [[The Alchemist (musician)|The Alchemist]] and others. Price went on to direct music videos for artists on 9th Wonder's Jamla Records label. In 2016, 9th Wonder's Jamla Records imprint signed a joint venture with [[Jay-Z]] and [[Roc Nation]].
In August 2010, Drake exchanged tweets with 9th Wonder on Twitter, expressing his desire to work with him again (the first time being the production of "Think Good Thoughts" featuring [[Phonte]] and [[Elzhi]] for his 2007 mixtape ''[[Comeback Season (mixtape)|Comeback Season]]''). It was revealed in October 2010 that 9th Wonder would be producing for Drake on his second album ''[[Take Care (album)|Take Care]]'', which was released on November 15, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|last=Horowitz |first=Steven J. |url=http://www.rap-up.com/2010/10/07/drake-shares-producers-on-second-album-still-uncertain-of-title/ |title=Drake Shares Producers on Second Album, Still Uncertain of Title |publisher=Rap-Up Magazine |date=October 7, 2010 |accessdate=October 11, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101010102448/http://www.rap-up.com/2010/10/07/drake-shares-producers-on-second-album-still-uncertain-of-title/| archivedate= October 10, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> However, a month prior to the release, 9th Wonder said in an interview that he would not appear on ''Take Care'' due to [[A&R]] issues.<ref>{{cite news|last=Iraheta|first=Mark|title=9th Wonder Will Not Appear on Drake's 'Take Care'|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2011/10/9th-wonder-will-not-appear-on-drakes-take-care|accessdate=October 16, 2011|newspaper=Complex Magazine|date=October 12, 2011}}</ref>
Singer [[Chris Brown (American entertainer)|Chris Brown]] recorded a series of rap freestyles over 9th Wonder beats. The first was released on July 18, 2011, on YouTube under the title "Real Hip Hop #3." This was followed a day later by "Real Hip Hop #4" featuring [[Kevin McCall]]. These tracks were included in Brown's rap mixtape ''Boy In Detention'', released on August 5, 2011.<ref name=9th-brownmixtape>{{cite news|last=Markman|first=Rob|title=Chris Brown Drops Rap Mixtape, Boy In Detention|url=http://rapfix.mtv.com/2011/08/05/chris-brown-drops-rap-mixtape-boy-in-detention/|accessdate=August 5, 2011|publisher=MTV|date=August 5, 2011}}</ref>
9th Wonder produced [[Jill Scott]]'s "Beautiful Love" ft. [[BJ The Chicago Kid]] on her 2015 album release "Woman". Rising Star [[Anderson .Paak]] also sought out 9th Wonder's production for "The Season" and "Without You" featuring [[Rapsody]] on his breakthrough release ''[[Malibu (album)|Malibu]]'' released coincidentally on 9th Wonder's birthday, January 15, 2016. 9th Wonder also collaborated with [[Big Boi]] of [[Outkast]] for the song "Put It On Her" for his release [[Big Grams]] in 2015. In 2017, [[Kendrick Lamar]] tapped 9th Wonder to produce [[Duckworth (song)|DUCKWORTH.]], the final track on his 4th studio album, ''[[Damn (Kendrick Lamar album)|DAMN]]'', where Kendrick tells the backstory of the meeting between his father and [[Anthony Tiffith]], also known as "Top Dawg" from [[Top Dawg Entertainment|TDE]].
==Hip hop professor and academia== 2007 saw a sideline move into music academia for 9th Wonder when he, along with [[Christopher "Play" Martin]] from hip hop group [[Kid-n-Play]], was appointed Artist-In-Residence by the Chancellor of [[North Carolina Central University]], and began instructing a hip hop history class in NCCU's Music Dept.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nccu.edu/directory/details.cfm?id=pdouthit&search=&department=Music |title=Online Campus Directory |publisher=Nccu.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-12-07}}</ref>
His role as a music professor has proven an ongoing one as in January 2010 it was announced that 9th Wonder would co-teach a class titled "Sampling Soul" with Dr. Mark Anthony Neal at Duke University.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.xxlmag.com/online/?p=67160 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130209234152/http://www.xxlmag.com/online/?p=67160 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-02-09 |title=9th Wonder to Teach Course at Duke University | XXL |publisher=Xxlmag.com |date=2010-01-07 |accessdate=2012-12-07 }}</ref> In an interview with [[HitQuarters]], he explained the reason for the move into academia: "Educating the youth on where hip-hop comes from and the history of it, using the records we use, gives hip-hop a longer life. I decided to become an advocate of that."<ref name="hitquarters.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/opar/intrview_9thWonder_Interview.html |title=Interview With 9th Wonder |publisher=[[HitQuarters]]|date=May 31, 2010 |accessdate=Jun 15, 2010}}</ref> 9th Wonder also recently took on a course titled "Intro To Hip Hop Production" <ref>[https://trinity.duke.edu/directory/people/d]</ref>
9th has only continued his trek into the world of education, recently receiving acceptance from [[Harvard University]] to become a fellow in the Hip Hop Archive. 9th will spend three years working on a research project at Harvard’s W.E.B. Dubois Institute. For 9th's project titled "These Are The Breaks" he will be researching the original records that created his top 10 produced albums. He recently told XXL that he one day hopes to leave producing behind for good to focus on academics. A documentary also created by Kenneth Price, "The Hip-Hop Fellow" chronicled 9th becoming a W.E.B. Dubois Fellow at [[Harvard University]] under the direction Dr. [[Henry Louis Gates, Jr.]] and Dr. Marcy Morgan at the Dubois Institute at The Hutchins Center.
He has continued his involvement with higher education by lecturing at various universities across the United States. In September 2012, 9th Wonder visited the [http://www.umich.edu/ University of Michigan] to speak on his beginnings in the music industry and hip hop's role in the classroom. His involvement with some of the top academic institutions in the country has validated hip hop as a true art form. 9th Wonder served as Artist In Residence at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] in the Spring of 2016. In March 2017, 9th Wonder was the Artist in Residence at the [[University of Virginia]], giving his final lecture in [[The Rotunda (University of Virginia)|The Rotunda]] on the University grounds. Several other hip hop artists have found themselves on similar paths into the education realm including [[Questlove]] of [[The Roots]] and [[Bun B]] of [[UGK]]. 9th is currently Artist of Residence at [[North Carolina Central University]] and [[Duke University]].
9th Wonder was also appointed to the Executive Committee of Hip-Hop and Rap at The [[National Museum of African American History and Culture]] at [[The Smithsonian]] in Washington, DC. He also has an exhibit on the 4th Floor in the Music Crossroads Section.

(with Explicit) * 2015: ''Indie 500'' (with [[Talib Kweli]]) * 2015: ''[[Brighter Daze]]'' (with [[Murs (rapper)|Murs]]) * 2017: ''The Lost Tapes - EP'' (with Mr. Cheeks)
