revision.comment: Alter: template type. Add: pages, url, arxiv, date, volume, journal, issue, pmid. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
'''Homochirality''' is a uniformity of [[Chirality (chemistry)|chirality]], or handedness. Objects are ''chiral'' when they cannot be superposed on their mirror images. For example, the left and right hands of a human are approximately mirror images of each other but are not their own mirror images, so they are ''chiral''. In [[biology]], 19 of the 20 natural [[amino acid]]s are homochiral, being <small>L</small>-chiral (left-handed), while [[sugar]]s are <small>D</small>-chiral (right-handed).<ref name="Lehninger">{{cite book |last1=Nelson, Lehninger et al |title=Lehninger Principles of Biochemistry |date=2008 |publisher=Macmillan |page=474}}</ref> ''Homochirality'' can also refer to ''enantiomerically pure'' substances in which all the constituents are the same [[enantiomer]] (a right-handed or left-handed version of an atom or molecule), but some sources discourage this use of the term.
It is unclear whether homochirality has a purpose, however, it appears to be a form of information storage.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Carroll|first1=James D.|title=A new definition of life|journal=Chirality|date=March 2009|volume=21|issue=3|pages=354–358|doi=10.1002/chir.20590|pmid=18571800}}</ref> One suggestion is that it reduces [[entropy]] barriers in the formation of large organized molecules.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Julian|first1=Ryan R.|last2=Myung|first2=Sunnie|last3=Clemmer|first3=David E.|title=Do Homochiral Aggregates Have an Entropic Advantage?|journal=The Journal of Physical Chemistry B|date=January 2005|volume=109|issue=1|pages=440–444|doi=10.1021/jp046478x|pmid=16851034}}</ref> It has been experimentally verified that amino acids form large aggregates in larger abundance from [[enantiopure]] substrates than from [[racemic]] ones.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}}
It is not clear whether homochirality emerged before or after life, and many mechanisms for its origin have been proposed.<ref name=jafarpour2017 /> Some of these models propose three distinct steps: ''mirror-symmetry breaking'' creates a minute enantiomeric imbalance, ''chiral amplification'' builds on this imbalance, and ''chiral transmission'' is the transfer of chirality from one set of molecules to another.
==In biology==
Amino acids are the building blocks of [[peptide]]s and [[enzyme]]s while sugar-peptide chains are the backbone of [[RNA]] and [[DNA]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Reusch|first1=William|title=Peptides & Proteins|url=https://www2.chemistry.msu.edu/faculty/reusch/virttxtjml/protein2.htm|website=Natural Products|publisher=Michigan State University|accessdate=8 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Lam|first1=Eric|chapter=Nucleic acids and proteins|editor-last1=Dey|editor-first1=P.M.|editor-last2=Harborne|editor-first2=J.B.|title=Plant Biochemistry.|date=1997|publisher=Elsevier|location=Burlington|isbn=9780080525723|page=315}}</ref> In biological organisms, amino acids appear almost exclusively in the left-handed form (<small>L</small>-amino acids) and sugars in the right-handed form (R-sugars).<ref>{{cite book |last1=Zubay |first1=Geoffrey |title=Origins of Life: On Earth and in the Cosmos |date=2000 |publisher=Elsevier |isbn=9780080497617 |page=96}}</ref>{{verify source|date=August 2018}} Since the enzymes catalyze reactions, they enforce homochirality on a great variety of other chemicals, including [[hormone]]s, toxins, fragrances and food flavors.<ref name=Seckbach>{{cite book|last1=Seckbach|first1=edited by Joseph|title=Genesis - in the beginning : precursors of life, chemical models and early biological evolution|date=2012|publisher=Springer|location=Dordrecht|isbn=9789400729407}}</ref>{{rp|493–494}} [[Glycine]] is achiral, as are some other non-[[proteinogenic]] amino acids are either achiral (such as [[dimethylglycine]]) or of the <small>D</small> enantiomeric form.
Biological organisms easily discriminate between molecules with different chiralities. This can affect physiological reactions such as smell and taste. [[Carvone]], a [[terpenoid]] found in [[essential oil]]s, smells like mint in its L-form and [[caraway]] in its R-form.<ref name=Seckbach/>{{rp|494}}{{verify source|date=August 2018}} [[Limonene]] tastes like lemons when right-handed and oranges when left-handed.<ref name=Hazen>{{cite book|last1=Hazen|first1=Robert M.|author-link=Robert Hazen|title=Genesis : the scientific quest for life's origins|date=2007|publisher=Joseph Henry|location=Washington, D.C.|isbn=9780309103107}}</ref>{{rp|168}}
Homochirality also affects the response to drugs. [[Thalidomide]], in its left-handed form, cures [[morning sickness]]; in its right-handed form, it causes birth defects.<ref name=Hazen/>{{rp|168}} Unfortunately, even if a pure left-handed version is administered, some of it can convert to the right-handed form in the patient.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Smith|first1=Silas|title=Chiral Toxicology: It's the Same Thing... Only Different|issue=1|url=http://toxsci.oxfordjournals.org/content/110/1/4.full|journal=Toxicological Sciences|volume=110|accessdate=16 April 2016|pages=4–30|doi=10.1093/toxsci/kfp097|pmid=19414517|date=July 2009}}</ref> Many drugs are available as both a [[racemic mixture]] (equal amounts of both chiralities) and an [[enantiopure drug]] (only one chirality). Depending on the manufacturing process, enantiopure forms can be more expensive to produce than stereochemical mixtures.<ref name=Hazen/>{{rp|168}}
Chiral preferences can also be found at a macroscopic level. Snail shells can be right-turning or left-turning helices, but one form or the other is strongly preferred in a given species. In the edible snail ''[[Helix pomatia]]'', only one out of 20,000 is left-helical.<ref name=Meierhenrich>{{cite book|last1=Meierhenrich|first1=Uwe|title=Amino acids and the asymmetry of life caught in the act of formation|date=2008|publisher=Springer|location=Berlin|isbn=9783540768869}}</ref>{{rp|61–62}} The coiling of plants can have a preferred chirality and even the chewing motion of cows has a 10% excess in one direction.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shaw|first1=Andrew M.|title=Astrochemistry From Astronomy to Astrobiology.|date=2007|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|location=Chichester|isbn=9780470091388|page=247}}</ref>
==Origins== ===Symmetry breaking=== Known mechanisms for the production of non-racemic mixtures from racemic starting materials include: asymmetric physical laws, such as the [[electroweak interaction]]; asymmetric environments, such as those caused by [[Circular polarization|circularly polarized]] light, [[Quartz|quartz crystal]]s, or the Earth's rotation; and statistical fluctuations during racemic synthesis.<ref name="Plasson2007">{{cite journal |last1=Plasson |first1=Raphaël |last2=Kondepudi |first2=Dilip K. |last3=Bersini |first3=Hugues |last4=Commeyras |first4=Auguste |last5=Asakura |first5=Kouichi |display-authors=3 |date=August 2007 |title=Emergence of homochirality in far-from-equilibrium systems: Mechanisms and role in prebiotic chemistry |journal=[[Chirality (journal)|Chirality]] |volume=19 |issue=8 |pages=589–600 |doi=10.1002/chir.20440 |issn=0899-0042 |pmid=17559107}} "Special Issue: Proceedings from the Eighteenth International Symposium on Chirality (ISCD-18), Busan, Korea, 2006"</ref> Once established, chirality would be selected for.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Clark |first=Stuart |authorlink=Stuart Clark (author) |date=July–August 1999 |title=Polarized Starlight and the Handedness of Life |journal=[[American Scientist]] |volume=87 |issue=4 |page=336 |bibcode=1999AmSci..87..336C |doi=10.1511/1999.4.336 |issn=0003-0996}}</ref> A small [[enantiomeric excess]] can be amplified into a large one by [[Autocatalysis#Asymmetric autocatalysis|asymmetric autocatalysis]], such as in the [[Soai reaction]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Shibata |first1=Takanori |last2=Morioka |first2=Hiroshi |last3=Hayase |first3=Tadakatsu |last4=Choji |first4=Kaori |last5=Soai |first5=Kenso |display-authors=3 |date=17 January 1996 |title=Highly Enantioselective Catalytic Asymmetric Automultiplication of Chiral Pyrimidyl Alcohol |journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society |volume=118 |issue=2 |pages=471–472 |doi=10.1021/ja953066g |issn=0002-7863}}</ref> In asymmetric autocatalysis, the catalyst is a chiral molecule, which means that a chiral molecule is catalysing its own production. An initial enantiomeric excess, such as can be produced by polarized light, then allows the more abundant enantiomer to outcompete the other.<ref name="Soai2001">{{cite journal |last1=Soai |first1=Kenso |last2=Sato |first2=Itaru |last3=Shibata |first3=Takanori |year=2001 |title=Asymmetric autocatalysis and the origin of chiral homogeneity in organic compounds |journal=The Chemical Record |volume=1 |issue=4 |pages=321–332 |doi=10.1002/tcr.1017 |issn=1528-0691 |pmid=11893072}}</ref>
One supposition is that the discovery of an enantiomeric imbalance in molecules in the [[Murchison meteorite]] supports an extraterrestrial origin of homochirality: there is evidence for the existence of [[Circular polarization|circularly polarized light]] originating from [[Mie scattering]] on aligned interstellar dust particles which may trigger the formation of an [[enantiomeric excess]] within chiral material in space.<ref name=Meierhenrich/>{{rp|123–124}} Interstellar and near-stellar magnetic fields can align dust particles in this fashion.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Helman |first=Daniel S |date=6 July 2018 |title=Galactic Distribution of Chirality Sources of Organic Molecules |journal=Acta Astronautica |volume=151 |pages=595–602 |doi=10.1016/j.actaastro.2018.07.008 |issn=0094-5765|bibcode=2018AcAau.151..595H |arxiv=1612.06720 }}</ref> Another speculation (the Vester-Ulbricht hypothesis) suggests that fundamental chirality of physical processes such as that of the beta decay (see [[Parity (physics)|Parity violation]]) leads to slightly different half-lives of biologically relevant molecules. Homochirality may also result from [[spontaneous absolute asymmetric synthesis]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://guava.physics.uiuc.edu/~nigel/courses/569/Essays_Fall2006/files/Rajan.pdf|title=How did protein amino acids get left-handed while sugars got right-handed?|first=Aruna|last=Rajan|publisher=Term Paper for Physics 569*|accessdate=June 18, 2014}}</ref><ref name=soai_interview>{{cite journal | journal= Highlights in Chemical Science |year= 2008 |issue= 5 |url= http://www.rsc.org/Publishing/ChemScience/Volume/2008/05/Kenso_Soai_interview.asp |title= Interview: In the beginning... |accessdate=June 18, 2014 }}</ref>
It is also possible that homochirality is simply a result of the natural autoamplification process of life—that either the formation of life as preferring one chirality or the other was a chance rare event which happened to occur with the chiralities we observe, or that all chiralities of life emerged rapidly but due to catastrophic events and strong competition, the other unobserved chiral preferences were wiped out by the preponderance and metabolic, enantiomeric enrichment from the 'winning' chirality choices.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Ermann |first1=L |title=Homochirality: the key to unlocking the origin of life? |journal=Applied Theoretical Biology |date=2013 |volume=7 |issue=10 |pages=21–37}}</ref> The emergence of chirality consensus as a natural autoamplification process has been associated with the [[2nd law of thermodynamics]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Cause of chirality consensus | author= Jaakkola, S., Sharma, V. and Annila, A.| journal = Curr. Chem. Biol. | year=2008| volume= 2 | issue=2| pages=53–58 | doi=10.2174/187231308784220536 |url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/ben/ccb/2008/00000002/00000002/art00005 | arxiv=0906.0254}}</ref>
===Amplification=== ====Theory==== [[File:Frank's model phase portrait.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Phase portrait of Frank's model: starting from almost everywhere in <small>L</small>-<small>D</small> plane (except <small>L</small> = <small>D</small> line), the system approaches to one of the homochiral states]] In 1953, [[Frederick Charles Frank|Charles Frank]] proposed a model to demonstrate that homochirality is a consequence of [[autocatalysis]].<ref name="frank1953">{{cite journal |last1=Frank |first1=F.C. |year=1953 |title=On spontaneous asymmetric synthesis |journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta |volume=11 |pages=459–463 |doi=10.1016/0006-3002(53)90082-1}}</ref> In his model the <small>L</small> and <small>D</small> enantiomers of a chiral molecule are autocatalytically produced from an achiral molecule A
:A + <small>L</small> → 2<small>L</small>,{{pad}}A + <small>D</small> → 2<small>D</small>
while suppressing each other through a reaction that he called ''mutual antagonism''
:<small>L</small> + <small>D</small> → ∅. In this model the racemic state is unstable in the sense that the slightest enantiomeric excess will be amplified to a completely homochiral state. This can be shown by computing the reaction rates from the [[law of mass action]]: :<math chem>\begin{align} \frac{d[\ce L]}{dt} &= k_a [\ce L] - k_d \ce{[L] [D]}\\ \frac{d[\ce D]}{dt} &= k_a [\ce D] - k_d \ce{[L] [D]}, \end{align}</math> where <math>k_a</math> is the rate constant for the autocatalytic reactions, <math>k_d</math> is the rate constant for mutual antagonism reaction, and the concentration of A is kept constant for simplicity. By defining the enantiomeric excess <math>\Phi</math> as :<math chem>\Phi = \frac{[\ce D] - [\ce L]}{[\ce D] + [\ce L]},</math> we can compute the rate of change of enatiomeric excess using [[chain rule]] from the rate of change of the concentrations of enantiomeres <small>L</small> and <small>D</small>. :<math chem> \frac{d\Phi}{dt} = \left(\frac{2k_d \ce{[L] [D]}}{[\ce D] + [\ce L]}\right)\Phi. </math> Linear stability analysis of this equation shows that the racemic state <math>\Phi = 0</math> is unstable. Starting from [[almost everywhere]] in the concentration space, the system evolves to a homochiral state.
It is generally understood that autocatalysis alone does not yield to homochirality, and the presence of the mutually antagonistic relationship between the two enantiomers is necessary for the instability of the racemic mixture. However, recent studies show that homochirality could be achieved from autocatalysis in the absence of the mutually antagonistic relationship, but the underlying mechanism for symmetry-breaking is different.<ref name="jafarpour2017">{{cite journal |last1=Jafarpour |first1=Farshid |last2=Biancalani |first2=Tommaso |last3=Goldenfeld |first3=Nigel |year=2017 |title=Noise-induced symmetry breaking far from equilibrium and the emergence of biological homochirality |journal=Physical Review E |volume=95 |issue=3 |pages=032407 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevE.95.032407|pmid=28415353 |bibcode=2017PhRvE..95c2407J }}</ref><ref name="jafarpour2015">{{cite journal |last1=Jafarpour |first1=Farshid |last2=Biancalani |first2=Tommaso |last3=Goldenfeld |first3=Nigel |year=2015 |title=Noise-induced mechanism for biological homochirality of early life self-replicators |journal=Physical Review Letters |volume=115 |issue=15 |pages=158101 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.115.158101|pmid=26550754 |arxiv=1507.00044 |bibcode=2015PhRvL.115o8101J }}</ref>
====Experiments==== There are several laboratory experiments that demonstrate how a small amount of one enantiomer at the start of a reaction can lead to a large excess of a single enantiomer as the product. For example, the Soai reaction is [[autocatalysis|autocatalytic]]. If the reaction is started with some of one of the product enantiomers already present, the product acts as an [[Enantioselective synthesis|enantioselective]] catalyst for production of more of that same enantiomer.<ref name=shibata>{{cite journal|title=Highly Enantioselective Catalytic Asymmetric Automultiplication of Chiral Pyrimidyl Alcohol|author1=Takanori Shibata |author2=Hiroshi Morioka |author3=Tadakatsu Hayase |author4=Kaori Choji |author5=Kenso Soai | journal = [[J. Am. Chem. Soc.]] | year=1996| volume= 118 | issue=2| pages=471–472 | doi=10.1021/ja953066g}}</ref> The initial presence of just 0.2 [[Equivalent (chemistry)|equivalent]] one enantiomer can lead to up to 93% [[enantiomeric excess]] of the product.
[[Image:Soai autocatalysis.png|center|500px]]
Another study<ref name=mathew>{{cite journal|title=Amplification of Enantiomeric Excess in a Proline-Mediated Reaction| author= Suju P. Mathew, Hiroshi Iwamura and [[Donna G. Blackmond]] | journal = [[Angewandte Chemie International Edition]] | volume = 43| issue = 25 | date=21 June 2004| pages= 3317–3321|doi=10.1002/anie.200453997|pmid=15213963}}</ref> concerns the [[proline]] catalyzed [[aminoxylation]] of [[propionaldehyde]] by [[nitrosobenzene]]. In this system, a small enantiomeric excess of catalyst leads to a large enantiomeric excess of product.
[[Image:Homochiralproline.png|center|500px]]
[[Serine octamer cluster]]s<ref>{{cite journal | title = Chiroselective Self-Directed Octamerization of Serine: Implications for Homochirogenesis | author = Cooks, R. G., Zhang, D., Koch, K. J. | journal = [[Anal. Chem.]] | volume = 73 | issue = 15 | pages = 3646–3655 | doi = 10.1021/ac010284l | year = 2001 | pmid=11510829}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | title = Serine Octamers: Cluster Formation, Reactions, and Implications for Biomolecule Homochirality | author = Nanita, S., Cooks, R. G. | journal = [[Angew. Chem. Int. Ed.]] | year = 2006 | volume = 45 | issue = 4 | pages = 554–569 | doi = 10.1002/anie.200501328 | pmid = 16404754}}</ref> are also contenders. These clusters of 8 serine molecules appear in mass spectrometry with an unusual homochiral preference, however there is no evidence that such clusters exist under non-ionizing conditions and amino acid phase behavior is far more prebiotically relevant.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Spoilt for choice: assessing phase behaviour models for the evolution of homochirality |author1=Donna G. Blackmond |author2=Martin Klussmann | journal = [[Chem. Commun.]] | year = 2007 | pages = 3990–3996 | doi = 10.1039/b709314b | pmid = 17912393 | issue = 39}}</ref> The recent observation that partial [[Sublimation (chemistry)|sublimation]] of a 10% enantioenriched sample of [[leucine]] results in up to 82% enrichment in the sublimate shows that enantioenrichment of amino acids could occur in space.<ref>{{cite journal | title = An astrophysically relevant mechanism for amino acid enantiomer enrichment |author1=Stephen P. Fletcher |author2=Richard B. C. Jagt |author3=Ben L. Feringa | journal = [[Chem. Commun.]] | volume = 2007 | year = 2007 | pages = 2578–2580 | doi = 10.1039/b702882b | pmid = 17579743 | issue = 25}}</ref> Partial sublimation processes can take place on the surface of meteors where large variations in temperature exist. This finding may have consequences for the development of the [[Mars Organic Detector]] scheduled for launch in 2013 which aims to recover trace amounts of amino acids from the Mars surface exactly by a sublimation technique.
A high asymmetric amplification of the [[enantiomeric excess]] of sugars are also present in the [[amino acid]] catalyzed asymmetric formation of [[carbohydrates]]<ref name=Engqvist>{{cite journal| title=Plausible origins of homochirality in the amino acid catalyzed neogenesis of carbohydrates|author1=Armando Córdova |author2=Magnus Engqvist |author3=Ismail Ibrahem |author4=Jesús Casas |author5=Henrik Sundén | journal=[[Chem. Commun.]] | volume=15| pages= 2047–2049 |year=2005 | doi=10.1039/b500589b | pmid=15834501 | issue=15}}</ref>
One classic study involves an experiment that takes place in the laboratory.<ref name=kondepudi>{{cite journal|title=Chiral Symmetry Breaking in Sodium Chlorate Crystallization| author= Kondepudi, D. K., Kaufman, R. J. & Singh, N.| journal= [[Science (journal)|Science]] | volume = 250 | pages = 975–976|year=1990|doi=10.1126/science.250.4983.975|pmid=17746924|issue=4983|bibcode = 1990Sci...250..975K }}</ref> When [[sodium chlorate]] is allowed to [[crystallization|crystallize]] from water and the collected crystals examined in a [[polarimeter]], each crystal turns out to be chiral and either the [[Levorotation|<small>L</small>]] form or the [[Dextrorotation|<small>D</small>]] form. In an ordinary experiment the amount of <small>L</small> crystals collected equals the amount of <small>D</small> crystals (corrected for statistical effects). However, when the sodium chlorate solution is stirred during the crystallization process the crystals are either exclusively <small>L</small> or exclusively <small>D</small>. In 32 consecutive crystallization experiments 14 experiments deliver <small>D</small>-crystals and 18 others <small>L</small>-crystals. The explanation for this symmetry breaking is unclear but is related to [[autocatalysis]] taking place in the [[nucleation]] process.
In a related experiment, a crystal suspension of a racemic [[amino acid]] derivative continuously stirred, results in a 100% crystal phase of one of the enantiomers because the enantiomeric pair is able to equilibrate in solution (compare with [[dynamic kinetic resolution]]).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Noorduin|first1=Wim L.|last2=Izumi|first2=Toshiko|last3=Millemaggi|first3=Alessia|last4=Leeman|first4=Michel|last5=Meekes|first5=Hugo|last6=Van Enckevort|first6=Willem J. P.|last7=Kellogg|first7=Richard M.|last8=Kaptein|first8=Bernard|last9=Vlieg|first9=Elias|last10=Blackmond|first10=Donna G.|title=Emergence of a Single Solid Chiral State from a Nearly Racemic Amino Acid Derivative|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|date=January 2008|volume=130|issue=4|pages=1158–1159|doi=10.1021/ja7106349|pmid=18173274|url=https://pure.rug.nl/ws/files/14468157/2008JAmChemSocNoorduin.pdf}}</ref>
===Transmission=== Many strategies in [[asymmetric synthesis]] are built on chiral transmission. Especially important is the so-called [[organocatalysis]] of organic reactions by proline for example in [[Mannich reaction]]s.
==Optical resolution in racemic amino acids== There exists no theory elucidating correlations among <small>L</small>-amino acids. If one takes, for example, [[alanine]], which has a small [[methyl]] group, and [[phenylalanine]], which has a larger [[benzyl]] group, a simple question is in what aspect, <small>L</small>-alanine resembles <small>L</small>-phenylalanine more than <small>D</small>-phenylalanine, and what kind of mechanism causes the selection of all <small>L</small>-amino acids. Because it might be possible that alanine was <small>L</small> and phenylalanine was <small>D</small>.
It was reported<ref name=kojo>{{cite journal|author1=S. Kojo |author2=H. Uchino |author3=M. Yoshimura |author4=K. Tanaka |title = Racemic D,L-asparagine causes enantiomeric excess of other coexisting racemic D,L-amino acids during recrystallization: a hypothesis accounting for the origin of L-amino acids in the biosphere.| journal = [[Chem. Comm.]] | pages= 2146–2147 | year= 2004|doi = 10.1039/b409941a|pmid=15467844|issue=19}}</ref> in 2004 that excess racemic [[asparagine|<small>D</small>,<small>L</small>-asparagine]] (Asn), which spontaneously forms crystals of either isomer during recrystallization, induces asymmetric resolution of a co-existing racemic amino acid such as [[arginine]] (Arg), [[aspartic acid]] (Asp), [[glutamine]] (Gln), [[histidine]] (His), [[leucine]] (Leu), [[methionine]] (Met), [[phenylalanine]] (Phe), [[serine]] (Ser), [[valine]] (Val), [[tyrosine]] (Tyr), and [[tryptophan]] (Trp). The [[enantiomeric excess]] {{math|ee {{=}} 100 ×(<small>L</small>-<small>D</small>)/(<small>L</small>+<small>D</small>)}} of these amino acids was correlated almost linearly with that of the inducer, i.e., Asn. When recrystallizations from a mixture of 12 <small>D</small>,<small>L</small>-amino acids (Ala, Asp, Arg, Glu, Gln, His, Leu, Met, Ser, Val, Phe, and Tyr) and excess <small>D</small>,<small>L</small>-Asn were made, all amino acids with the same configuration with Asn were preferentially co-crystallized.<ref name=kojo/> It was incidental whether the enrichment took place in <small>L</small>- or <small>D</small>-Asn, however, once the selection was made, the co-existing amino acid with the same configuration at the α-carbon was preferentially involved because of thermodynamic stability in the crystal formation. The maximal ee was reported to be 100%. Based on these results, it is proposed that a mixture of racemic amino acids causes spontaneous and effective optical resolution, even if asymmetric synthesis of a single amino acid does not occur without an aid of an optically active molecule.
This is the first study elucidating reasonably the formation of chirality from racemic amino acids with experimental evidences.
==History of term== This term was introduced by [[William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin|Kelvin]] in 1904, the year that he published his Baltimore Lecture of 1884. Kelvin used the term homochirality as a relationship between two molecules, i.e. two molecule are homochiral if they have the same chirality.<ref name=Engqvist/><ref name=morris>{{cite book|last1=Morris|first1=David G.|title=Stereochemistry|date=2001|publisher=Royal Society of Chemistry|location=Cambridge|isbn=978-1-84755-194-8|page=30}}</ref> Recently, however, homochiral has been used in the same sense as [[enantiomer]]ically pure. This is permitted in some journals (but not encouraged),<ref>{{cite book|last1=Anslyn|first1=Eric V.|last2=Dougherty|first2=Dennis A.|title=Modern physical organic chemistry|date=2006|publisher=University Science Books|location=Sausalito, Calif.|isbn=9781891389313}}</ref>{{rp|342}}<ref>However, the message can be confusing. In {{cite journal|last1=Moss|first1=G. P.|title=Basic terminology of stereochemistry (IUPAC Recommendations 1996)|journal=Pure and Applied Chemistry|date=1 January 1996|volume=68|issue=12|pages=2193–2222|doi=10.1351/pac199668122193|url=https://www.degruyter.com/downloadpdf/j/pac.1996.68.issue-12/pac199668122193/pac199668122193.pdf|accessdate=7 May 2018}}, the entry for ''Enantiomerically Pure/Enantiopure'' says "Use of homochiral as a synonym is strongly discouraged"; but the entry for ''Homochiral'' says "See ''enantiomerically pure/enantiopure''."</ref> its meaning changing into the preference of a process or system for a single [[optical isomer]] in a pair of isomers in these journals.
==See also== * [[Chiral life concept]] - of artificially synthesizing chiral-mirror version of life * [[CIP system]] * [[Stereochemistry]] * [[Pfeiffer Effect]] * [[Unsolved problems in chemistry]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== {{Refbegin}} *{{cite news|last1=Bailey|first1=Jeremy|title=Stellar Circular Polarization and Biomolecular Homochirality|url=http://scienceweek.com/1998/sw980828.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101130094258/http://scienceweek.com/1998/sw980828.htm|archive-date=30 November 2010|accessdate=5 May 2018|work=ScienceWeek|date=28 August 1998}} *{{cite newspaper |last1=Ball |first1=Philip |title=A circular argument? |newspaper=Nature |date=24 April 2009 |doi=10.1038/news.2009.390}} *{{cite news |last1=Brazil |first1=Rachel |title=The origin of homochirality |url=https://www.chemistryworld.com/feature/the-origin-of-homochirality/9073.article |accessdate=10 August 2018 |work=Chemistry World |date=26 October 2015 |language=en}} *{{cite news release|last1=Blackmond|first1=Donna G.|last2=Miller|first2=Rom|title=How left-handed amino acids got ahead: a demonstration of the evolution of biological homochirality in the lab|url=https://www.imperial.ac.uk/college.asp?P=5343|accessdate=5 May 2018|work=www.imperial.ac.uk|agency=Imperial College London|date=21 June 2004|language=en}} *{{cite book |last1=Guijarro |first1=Albert |last2=Yus |first2=Miguel |title=The origin of chirality in the molecules of life : a revision from awareness to the current theories and perspectives of this unsolved problem |date=2008 |publisher=Royal Society of Chemistry |location=Cambridge, UK |isbn=9780854041565}} *{{cite journal|last1=Hegstrom|first1=Roger A.|last2=Kondepudi|first2=Dilip K.|title=The Handedness of the Universe|journal=Scientific American|date=1990|volume=262|issue=1|pages=108–115|jstor=24996649}} *{{cite journal|last1=Jafarpour|first1=Farshid|last2=Biancalani|first2=Tommaso|last3=Goldenfeld|first3=Nigel|title=Noise-induced symmetry breaking far from equilibrium and the emergence of biological homochirality|journal=Physical Review E|date=10 March 2017|volume=95|issue=3|pages=032407|doi=10.1103/PhysRevE.95.032407|pmid=28415353|bibcode=2017PhRvE..95c2407J}} *{{cite book |last=Nansheng |first=Zhao |chapter=The role of homochirality in evolution|editor-last1=Zucchi |editor-first1=C. |editor-last2=Caglioti |editor-first2=L. |editor-last3=Pályi |editor-first3=G. |title=Advances in BioChirality. |date=1999 |publisher=Elsevier |location=Burlington |isbn=9780080526621 |doi=10.1016/B978-008043404-9/50008-5|pages=105–114}} *{{cite news|last1=Rouhi|first1=A. Maureen|title=On the Genesis of Homochirality|url=http://pubs.acs.org/cen/news/8224/8225earlyscicon.html|accessdate=5 May 2018|work=Chemical & Engineering News|publisher=American Chemical Society|date=17 June 2004}} *{{cite news |last1=Sedbrook |first1=Danielle |title=Must the Molecules of Life Always be Left-Handed or Right-Handed? |url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/space/must-all-molecules-life-be-left-handed-or-right-handed-180959956/ |accessdate=10 August 2018 |work=Smithsonian |date=28 July 2016 |language=en}} {{Refend}}

Photonics TechnologyWorld November 1998. *[http://agenda.albanova.se/conferenceDisplay.py?confId=322 Origins of Homochirality]. Conference in Nordita Stockholm, February 2008.

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Human nature}} {{Other uses}} The '''human condition''' is "the characteristics, key events, and situations which compose the essentials of [[human]] existence, such as birth, growth, emotionality, aspiration, conflict, and mortality".<ref>"[[wikt:human condition|human condition]]" entry at [[Wiktionary]]</ref> This is a very broad topic which has been and continues to be pondered and analyzed from many perspectives, including those of [[religion]], [[philosophy]], [[history]], [[art]], [[literature]], [[anthropology]], [[psychology]], and [[biology]].
As a [[terminology|literary term]], "the human condition" is typically used in the context of ambiguous subjects such as the [[meaning of life]] or [[morality|moral concerns]].<ref name="lit">[http://learn.lexiconic.net/humancondition.htm The human condition in literature]</ref>
==Some perspectives==
Each [[major religious groups|major religion]] has definitive beliefs regarding the human condition. For example, [[Buddhism]] [[Four Noble Truths|teaches]] that life is a perpetual cycle of [[dukkha|suffering]], death, and rebirth from which humans can be liberated via the [[Noble Eightfold Path]]. Meanwhile, [[Christianity]] teaches that humans are born in a [[original sin|sinful condition]] and are [[Christian views on hell|doomed]] in the [[afterlife]] unless they receive [[Salvation (Christianity)|salvation]] through [[Jesus|Jesus Christ]].
Philosophers have provided many perspectives. An influential ancient view was that of the ''[[The Republic (Plato)|Republic]]'' in which [[Plato]] explored the question "what is justice?" and postulated that it is not primarily a matter among individuals but of [[society]] as a whole, prompting him to devise a [[utopia]]. Two thousand years later [[René Descartes]] declared "[[Cogito ergo sum|I think, therefore I am]]" because he believed the human mind, particularly its faculty of [[reason]], to be the primary determiner of [[truth]]; for this he is often credited as the father of modern philosophy.<ref>[[Bertrand Russell]] (2004) [https://books.google.com/books?id=Ey94E3sOMA0C&pg=PA511 ''History of Western Philosophy''] pp.511, 516–7</ref> One such modern school, [[existentialism]], attempts to reconcile an individual's sense of disorientation and confusion in a universe believed to be [[absurdism|absurd]].
Many works of literature provide perspective on the human condition.<ref name="lit"/> One famous example is [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare's]] monologue "[[All the world's a stage]]" that pensively summarizes seven phases of human life.
Psychology has many theories, such as [[Maslow's hierarchy of needs]] and the notion of [[identity crisis]]. It also has various methods, e.g. the [[logotherapy]] developed by [[The Holocaust|Holocaust]] survivor [[Viktor Frankl]] to discover and affirm human meaning. Another method, [[cognitive behavioral therapy]], has become a widespread treatment for [[major depressive disorder|clinical depression]].<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Driessen Ellen |author2=Hollon Steven D | year = 2010 | title = Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Mood Disorders: Efficacy, Moderators and Mediators | url = | journal = Psychiatric Clinics of North America | volume = 33 | issue = 3| pages = 537–55 | doi=10.1016/j.psc.2010.04.005 | pmid=20599132 | pmc=2933381}}</ref>
Ever since 1859, when [[Charles Darwin]] published ''[[On the Origin of Species]]'', the biological [[scientific theory|theory]] of [[evolution]] has been significant. The theory posits that the human [[species]] is related to all others, living and extinct, and that [[natural selection]] is the primary survival factor. This has provided a basis for new beliefs, e.g. [[social Darwinism]], and for new [[technology]], e.g. [[antibiotics]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Gladki A, Kaczanowski S, Szczesny P, Zielenkiewicz P |title=The evolutionary rate of antibacterial drug targets |journal=BMC Bioinformatics |volume=14 |pages=36 |date=February 2013 |pmid=23374913 |url= |doi=10.1186/1471-2105-14-36 |pmc=3598507}}</ref>
==Use of the term==
Notable uses of the term "the human condition" include [[André Malraux]]'s novel ''[[Man's Fate]]'', [[René Magritte]]'s painting ''[[The Human Condition (painting)|La Condition Humaine]]'', [[Hannah Arendt]]'s [[The Human Condition (book)|political philosophy]], and [[Masaki Kobayashi]]'s [[The Human Condition (film series)|film trilogy]].
==See also== * [[Human nature]] * [[Human self-reflection]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Human Condition}} [[Category:Existentialist concepts]] [[Category:Personal life]] [[Category:Philosophy of life]] [[Category:Humans]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues|section=| {{external links|date=September 2018}} {{Orphan|date=September 2018}} }} {{Infobox person/Wikidata|fetchwikidata=ALL|onlysourced=yes|suppressfields=education}} '''Jedediah Aaker''' is a musician, performer, theatrical producer, and [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]]-area personality. A fixture on cable series ''[[Portlandia (TV series)|Portlandia]]'', he has appeared in more episodes than anyone besides the series' two leads.<ref>{{cite web |title=15 Things You Probably Didn’t Know About Portlandia |url=https://www.ifc.com/2014/12/15-things-you-probably-didnt-know-about-portlandia |date=December 2014 |website=''IFC'' |accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref> The PDX-native is also a multiple-award-winning, ''Whisker Wars''-celebrated competitive bearder who co-founded the Portland Beardsmen.<ref name="auto">{{cite web |last1=Jamie |first1=Hale |title=Portland beardsman Jedediah Aaker prepares for the World Beard and Moustache Championships |url=https://www.oregonlive.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2014/10/portlands_resident_beardsmen_j.html |date=23 October 2014 |website=''The Oregonian'' |accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref>
He has worn a Christmas sweater on the cover of ''[[The Portland Mercury]]'' and appeared as a shirtless model on the front page of ''[[Willamette Week]]''{{'}}s 2018 <q>Beer</q> issue.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://issuu.com/willametteweek/docs/44.18_-_willamette_week__february_2|title=44 18 willamette week, february 28, 2018|publisher=}}</ref> He has worked as bartender for a failing club featured on the fourth season of ''[[Bar Rescue]]'' and as host of Barfly Bus Tours.<ref>{{cite web |title=Panic Room on Bar Rescue: <q>They were setting us up to fail.</q> |url=https://www.wweek.com/arts/2015/07/28/panic-room-on-bar-rescue-they-were-setting-us-up-to-fail/ |date=28 July 2015 |website=Willamette Week |accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.barflybus.com|title=BarFly Bus Tours of Portland Oregon|website=BarFly Bus Tours of Portland Oregon}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paramountnetwork.com/episodes/n395kv/bar-rescue-ants-with-wings-bro-season-4-ep-25|title=Bar Rescue - Ants With Wings, Bro! - Paramount Network|website=Paramount Network}}</ref> ''The Daily Mail'' referred to him as a <q>Portland character</q> and <q>professional party host</q>, and alternative newspaper ''Willamette Week'' dubbed him a <q>beard-about-town</q>.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Brown |first1=Ruth |title=Headout: Puddin' Slam Ladies rassle in white goop: <q>It's empowering.</q> |url=http://www.wweek.com/portland/article-18956-headout-puddin-slam.html |date=20 March 2012 |website=''Willamette Week'' |accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref> In a 2018 feature article titled <q>Twilight of the Hipsters</q>, the French edition of [[Rolling Stone]] introduced Aaker as an <q>actor, concert booker, chauffeur for rock stars, and distributor of the Lucky Egg vending machines that he installs in bars.</q><ref name="auto1">{{cite web |last1=Saferis |first1=Camille |title=Le Crepuscule des Hipsters |url=https://www.scribd.com/document/377581449/2018-04-01-Rolling-Stone-Hors-Serie |date=April 2018 |website=''Rolling Stone'' |accessdate=15 August 2018}}</ref>
==''Portlandia''== ''Portlandia'' first entered the global consciousness after satirical music video <q>Dream of the ‘90s</q> premiered online in December 2010 and thrust [[Saturday Night Live]] star [[Fred Armisen]] between a motley assemblage of circus folk, exotic dancers, and idiosyncratically-styled local luminaries.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Wappler |first1=Margaret |title='Portlandia': Where the dream of the '90s lives on... |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2011/01/portlandia-where-the-dream-of-the-90s-lives-on-1.html |date=6 January 2011 |website="Los Angeles Times" |accessdate=15 August 2018}}</ref> Standing directly to the right of Armisen throughout the video while wearing only star-spangled swim briefs, black leather, and a sizable beard, Aaker stood out as the swiftly-trending clip sparked interest worldwide in the forthcoming sketch comedy series.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Scott |first1=Aaron |title=Portlanders Bid Mixed Goodbyes To 'Portlandia' |url=https://www.opb.org/artsandlife/article/portlandia-final-season-portland-oregon-reaction/ |date=24 January 2018 |website="OPB" |accessdate=15 August 2018}}</ref> In the process, Aaker soon became widely known as, in the words of ''Willamette Week'', <q>that guy in underwear and a leather jacket in the ‘Dream of the ‘90s’ clip.</q><ref>{{cite web |title=Willamette Geek: The Week in Geek |url=http://www.wweek.com/portland/blog-28088-willamette-geek-the-week-in-geek.html |date=16 January 2012 |website=''Willamette Week'' |accessdate=15 August 2018}}</ref>
In addition to serving as a [[Extra (acting)|background actor]] on several episodes, Aaker has played a scavenger hunt umpire, a member of Spyke’s wedding party, and a guest at [[List of Portlandia characters|Nina]]'s birthday party.<ref name="auto2">{{cite web |last1=Locker |first1=Melissa |title=The Citizens of Portlandia: Jedediah Aaker |url=https://www.ifc.com/shows/portlandia/blog/2014/01/citizens-of-portlandia-jedediah-aaker |website="IFC" |accessdate=15 August 2018}}</ref> Ranking the <q>Best and Worst</q> of the series’ third season, ''[[Portland Monthly]]'' critic John Chandler determined the <q>hirsute man-about-town</q> tied with a veteran theater actress for <q>Best Performance By A Local</q>. Although <q>Aaker plays himself (presumably)</q> in episodes four and five, Chandler wrote, <q>the man’s beard has star quality.</q><ref>{{cite web |last1=Chandler |first1=John |title=Portlandia Season 3: The Best and Worst So Far |url=https://www.pdxmonthly.com/articles/2013/1/31/portlandia-season-3 |date=31 January 2013 |website="Portland Monthly" |accessdate=15 August 2018}}</ref> By season four, Aaker had appeared in almost two dozen of the 37 episodes then filmed.<ref name="auto"/>
Additionally, he served as [[Kumail Nanjiani]]'s assistant on [[webisode]]s of IFC's travelogue series ''Kumail Tours Portland''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ifc.com/shows/portlandia/blog/2013/01/portlandia-kumail-visits-a-tiny-house-in-portlandia|title=Kumail Nanjiani visits Portlandia’s tiniest house|publisher=}}</ref> When the series finished its eighth and final season in the spring of 2018, its network [[IFC (U.S. TV channel)|IFC]] estimated that the collective number of Aaker's various performances ranked below only co-founders [[Armisen]] and [[Carrie Brownstein]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hutchinson |first1=Sean |title=15 Things You Probably Didn’t Know About Portlandia |url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/60769/15-things-you-probably-didnt-know-about-portlandia |date=29 December 2014 |website="Mental Floss" |accessdate=15 August 2018}}</ref>
==="Portraitlandia"=== In 2013, during a month-long residency at Portland’s Newspace Center for Photography, acclaimed [[San Francisco]] photographer Kirk Crippens sought out 45 PDX locals for a series of portraits eventually titled "Portraitlandia". Over the next year, according to ''Portland Monthly'', the <q>series went viral, drawing millions of eyes to the site of its photographer.</q><ref name="auto3">{{cite web |last1=Scott |first1=Aaron |title=Portraitlandia Asks Us: What Do We Look Like (NSFW) |url=https://www.pdxmonthly.com/articles/2014/1/17/portraitlandia-january-2014 |date=17 January 2014 |website=Portland Monthly |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref> Images from the Portraitlandia series would be exhibited at London's [[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]] in conjunction with the [[Taylor Wessing#Taylor Wessing Photographic Portrait Prize|Taylor Wessing Photographic Portrait Prize]] and toured the United States as part of the Photolucida exhibition.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Rosenberg |first1=David |title=Up-Close and Quirky Photos With the Glorious Residents of Portland |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/behold/2013/11/14/kirk_crippens_portraitlandia_examines_the_quirky_residents_of_portland_photos.html |date=14 November 2013 |website=Slate |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref>
Although Crippens told [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] that he’d <q>expected his work to stand in sharp contrast to the fictions</q> of ''Portlandia'', the artist found <q>significant overlap</q> – particularly so when the first episode he saw after beginning the project happened to showcase Aaker and another two planned subjects.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Brook |first1=Pete |title=Portraitlandia Confirms and Refutes Everything You Think About Portland |url=https://www.wired.com/2013/07/portraitlandia/ |date=10 July 2013 |website=Wired |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref> Aaker, <q>a man about town who owns his own lion suit,</q> was among Crittens’ favorite subjects.<ref name="auto3"/> For their shoot, Crittens said Aakers made available the roof of the nightclub where he tended bar and then asked the photographer <q>if I wanted him to curl up like a kitty in the ivy growing over the top of the roof. Yes, yes I did.</q><ref>{{cite web |last1=Jones |first1=Gregory Eddi |title=Interview with Kirk Crippens, the Artist Behind ‘Portraitlandia’ |url=https://petapixel.com/2013/10/29/interview-kirk-crippens-photographer-behind-portraitlandia/ |date=29 October 2013 |website="PetaPixel" |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref>
==Music== Aaker has been involved with several NW rock bands. He spent years playing bass for the Fabulous Miss Wendy, a performer who has toured with [[Slash (musician)|Slash]] and was lauded as the <q>sexiest rock star ever</q> by [[Revolver (magazine)|Revolver]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cavuto |first1=Robert |title=The Fabulous Miss Wendy – No One Can Stop Me! |url=http://guitarinternational.com/2012/09/17/wendy/ |date=17 September 2017 |website=Guitar International |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref> He’s a founding member and bassist of The Gnash, whose music he has compared to <q>a primer-gray broken down Camaro.</q><ref name="auto2"/> The group recently put out a split single on the [[Voodoo Doughnut Recordings]] label entitled <q>She Took My Doughnut (And Left Me the Hole)</q>.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.voodoodoughnutrecordings.com/artists/the-gnash/scuzz-rock-split/|title=Scuzz Rock Split • Voodoo Doughnut Recordings|publisher=}}</ref>
He’s currently a member of the re-united Lucky Thirteens with former Weaklings vocalist Bradly Battin.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/2255777-The-Lucky-Thirteens|title=The Lucky Thirteens|website=Discogs}}</ref> Battins and Aaker previously played together in short-lived 00s group DARLINS.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://store.cdbaby.com/cd/darlins|title=♫ A Last Time For Everything - Darlins. Listen @cdbaby|publisher=}}</ref> One venue owner explained the Lucky Thirteens’ sound as <q>fun, poppy-punk like you’d hear coming out of the jukebox ... back in 2000.</q><ref>{{cite web |title=Labor Temple Bar Resurrects Portland Punk Scene |url=http://www.coastweekend.com/cw/music/20180530/labor-temple-bar-resurrects-portland-punk-scene |date=30 May 2018 |website=Coast Weekend |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref>
For several years throughout the 2000s, Aaker served as frontman of glam metal group Diamond Tuck & The Privates – <q>an eight-piece band carefully culled from the lifers of the Portland rock scene.</q><ref>{{cite web |last1=Vegas |first1=Viva Las |title=Stripper Sluts Hit The Road With Portland's Two Hottest Rock Bands: Diamond Tuck & The Privates and Starantula |url=http://www.xmag.com/archives/11-12-jun04/feature2.html |date=June 2004 |website="Exotic Magazine" |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref> ''Willamette Week'' referred to their appearance on a (local punk mainstay) Club 21 compilation as <q>epic … buttrock.</q><ref>{{cite web |last1=Soule |first1=Sam |title=VARIOUS ARTISTS Club 21, Fuck Yeah! (Self-Released) |url=http://www.wweek.com/portland/blog-24039-various-artists-club-21-fuck-yeah-self-released.html |date=15 November 2006 |website=Willamette Week |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref>
==Theater== In 2009, Aaker and Diamond Tuck guitarist <q>Private</q> Mike Albano led the live band during performances of writer/director/producer Jeffery <q>Wonderful</q> Wilson’s rock opera ''Chariots of Rubber'' during performances at the [[Interstate Firehouse Cultural Center]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.portlandmercury.com/events/1489094/chariots-of-rubber|title=Chariots of Rubber|website=Portland Mercury}}</ref> A review from the [[Portland State University]] [[Daily Vanguard|Vanguard]], described the original score as <q>1980s metal with a dash of [[The Rocky Horror Picture Show|Rocky Horror Picture Show]].</q><ref>{{cite web |last1=Kinney |first1=Anita |title=The Passion of the Metal Areola Snatchers |url=http://psuvanguard.com/the-passion-of-the-metal-areola-snatchers/ |date=29 October 2009 |website=PSU Vanguard |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref>
The following year, Aaker and Wilson again joined forces as, respectively, producer and director of ''Hot Gun''.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Williams |first1=Lee |title=Original Performances on Unique Stages Reinvent Portland Theater |url=https://www.oregonlive.com/performance/index.ssf/2010/07/original_performances_on_uniqu.html |date=1 July 2010 |website=The Oregonian |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref> The <q>rock ’n’ roll re-imagining of the iconic blockbuster [[Top Gun]]</q> was performed live on stage at PDX nightclub [[Dante's]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hallet |first1=Allison |title=Top Gun: The Musical |url=https://www.portlandmercury.com/BlogtownPDX/archives/2010/04/09/top-gun-the-musical |date=9 April 2010 |website="The Portland Mercury" |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref>
In a review from ''Portland Monthly'', their critic admired the multimedia production’s deft manipulation of the original film – inserting previously-shot scenes of the stage actors into aerial battles – but found the comedy’s <q>laughs were loudest with the in-crowd. The novelty of seeing friends dressed funny, and/or comically incorporated into video footage, was the bulk of the fun.</q><ref>{{cite web |last1=Adams |first1=Anne |title=Between Theater and Bar |url=https://www.pdxmonthly.com/articles/2010/5/31/63110theater-bar-cp |website=Portland Monthly |date=31 May 2010 |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref> ''Willamette Week'', however, raved ''Hot Gun''’s <q>summer stock-'n'-roll aesthetic, artfully unchoreographed and shruggably brilliant, resembles an old movie naval pageant (coconut bras on bearded men, absent camp or shame) blessed with the underutilized talents peculiar to Portland ...</q><ref>{{cite web |last1=Horton |first1=Jay |title=Hot Gun (Wonderdiamond Productions) The Iceman Cometh |url=http://www.wweek.com/portland/article-12079-i-hot-gun-i-wonderdiamond-productions.html |date=8 June 2010 |website="Willamette Week" |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref>
A year later, Aaker brought John Walterich’s online-dating satire ''Brie'' to the stage of the Tonic Lounge for a brief run. ''Willamette Week'' critic Jonathan Frochtzwajg described the production as </q>a largely amateur, very tattooed cast ... scored live by rotating punk-rock acts.</q><ref>{{cite web |last1=Frochtzwajg |first1=Jonathan |title=Brie |url=https://issuu.com/willametteweek/docs/38.05_-_willamette_week__december_7 |date=7 December 2011 |website=Willamette Week |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref>
==Film== Aaker acted in the 2017 film ''Neil Stryker and the Tyrant of Time'' alongside TV icons [[Walter Koenig]] ([[Pavel Chekov|Ensign Pavel Chekov]])and [[David Ogden Stiers]] ([[List of M*A*S*H characters#Charles Winchester|Major Charles Emerson Winchester]]). <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt4394034/|title=Neil Stryker and the Tyrant of Time|publisher=|via=www.imdb.com}}</ref> That same year, he was a central figure in the 2017 documentary ''Thank You for Supporting the Arts'', which also features [[Gus Van Sant]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt7391464/|title=Thank You for Supporting the Arts|publisher=|via=www.imdb.com}}</ref> The doc explores the physical and emotional trauma suffered by author and exotic dancer Liv <q>Viva Las Vegas</q> Osthus following her fight against breast cancer and subsequent mastectomy.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Perry |first1=Douglas |title=Documentary about iconic Portland stripper Viva Las Vegas screens for local audiences |url=https://www.oregonlive.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2018/04/documentary_about_iconic_portl.html |date=30 April 2017 |website="The Oregonian" |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref> Osthus and Aaker were in a relationship for many years.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Osthus |first1=Liv |title=A Reality Show for Couples Therapy? Sign Us Up |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/23/fashion/sundaystyles/a-reality-show-for-couples-therapy-sign-us-up.html |date=23 April 2006 |website="New York Times" |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref> As the first to discover her disease, he plays a significant role in the film's coverage of her struggles.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lion |first1=Melissa |title=The Stripper Who Lost a Breast |url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/the-stripper-who-lost-a-breast |date=21 August 2009 |website=The Daily Beast |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref>
==Hosting== As a judge for the 2011 West Coast Beard and Mustache Championships, Aaker appeared in a 2011 episode of the ''Whisker Wars'' cable reality series. <q>You're not judging on what's the biggest or the longest but ... the grandest,</q> he told the ''Oregonian''. <q>It just has the magic glow ...</q><ref name="auto"/> He’s also regularly called upon to help select the winners of various events around the Portland area such as the Bacon Cup, the Iron Bartender competition, the horror short GuignolFest, and Portland’s inaugural Pudding Wrestling Massacre.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pdxpipeline.com/events/july-16-bacon-cup-ash-st-saloon-bacon-wrestling-strippers-music-recipes/|title=July 16: Bacon Cup @ Ash St Saloon - Bacon Wrestling, Strippers, Music, Recipes|date=15 July 2011|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.yelp.com/events/portland-iron-bartender-2010|title=Iron Bartender 2010, Portland, OR|website=Yelp}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://portlandtribune.com/pt/11-features/121371-bits--and--pieces|title=Bits & Pieces|first=Jason|last=Vondersmith|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wweek.com/portland/article-18956-headout-puddin-slam.html|title=Headout: Puddin' Slam|publisher=}}</ref> In a [[Vice (magazine)|Vice]] article that takes its title (<q>Every Vagina Is A Snowflake</q>) from a quote given by Aaker, the magazine noted that the <q>returning judge</q> brought his own props overseeing the beauty pageant for exotic dancers' nether regions.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Shepard |first1=Susan Elizabeth |title=Every Vagina Is a Snowflake: A Dispatch from Portland's Vagina Beauty Pageant |url=https://broadly.vice.com/en_us/article/qvddxv/every-vagina-is-a-snowflake-a-dispatch-from-portlands-vagina-beauty-pageant |date=5 August 2015 |website=Vice |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref>
==Bearding== Aaker has been cultivating his beard for more than ten years.<ref name="auto1"/> He’s become a notable figure in competitive bearding events, winning several freestyle awards, and can be seen in the first season of IFC series ''Whisker Wars''.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Rob |first1=Owen |title=IFC's 'Whisker Wars' Focuses on Competitive Beard Growing? Yes, It's an Oregon Thing, Too |url=https://www.oregonlive.com/movies/2011/07/competitive_beard_growing_yes_its_an_oregon_thing_too.html |date=31 July 2011 |website="The Oregonian" |accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref>
At the 2014 [[World Beard and Moustache Championships]] held inside Portland’s [[Keller Auditorium]], which hosted 300 contestants from ten countries, Aaker emerged as a fan favorite.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hale |first1=Jamie |title=Hairy Controversy Surrounds World Beard and Moustache Championships, Coming to Portland This Weekend |url=https://www.oregonlive.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2014/10/hairy_controversy_surrounds_wo.html |date=23 October 2014 |website=The Oregonian |accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref> ''The Oregonian'' reported that he "somehow got extra time, walking onstage in short shorts and a white fur coat, his red beard shaped into a flying V guitar, gyrating his belly to the roar of the crowd. He walked away with sixth place, but he stole the audience's heart."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hale |first1=Jamie |title=World Beard and Moustache Championships Draws Huge Crowd to Portland, Spirals Into Chaos Onstage |url=https://www.oregonlive.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2014/10/world_beard_and_moustache_cham_1.html |date=25 October 2014 |website=The Oregonian |accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref>
In 2012, Aaker helped found the Portland Beardsmen – a band of facial-hair enthusiasts who compete for prizes awarded on the merits of beard size, grooming, style, creativity, and other characteristics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portlandbeardsmen.com|title=Home|website=The Portland Beardsmen}}</ref> The nonprofit group raises funds for transportation to far-flung tournaments, and they also organize charitable efforts such as beard-wielded car washes.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Staff |first1=FOX 12 |title=Portland Beardsmen Surprise Moms with Flower Deliveries |url=http://www.kptv.com/story/31819718/portland-beardsmen-surprise-moms-with-flower-deliveries |date=25 October 2014 |website=KPTV |accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref> For their annual Beards N Roses drive each Mother’s Day, hirsute members don brightly-colored tights and tutus for delivering bouquets to Portland-area moms. Aaker helped originate the program six years ago to benefit the [[Uprise Books Project]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hale |first1=Jamie |title=Portland Beardsmen Don Tutus, Deliver Mother's Day Flowers Around the City |url=https://www.oregonlive.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2015/05/portland_beardsmen_don_tutus_d.html |date=9 May 2015 |website=The Oregonian |accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref>
===Portland Beardsmen=== On the evening of August 28, 2012, Aaker was among 13 bearded men detained at gunpoint by officers from the [[Portland Police Bureau|Portland police]] on the [[Burnside Bridge]] during what ''the Oregonian'' termed "a military-themed photo shoot for breast cancer awareness." <ref>{{cite web |last1=Bailey Jr. |first1=Everton |title=Rifle, body armor on Burnside Bridge lead to arrests during 'Beards for Breasts' photo shoot |url=https://www.oregonlive.com/portland/index.ssf/2012/08/rifle_body_armor_on_burnside_b.html |date=30 August 2012 |website=The Oregonian |accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref> After an unnamed observer’s [[9-1-1|911]] call alerted authorities about suspicious characters wearing camouflaged body armor, both sides of the bridge were closed for nearly an hour as the police investigated the situation. Two men were taken into custody for disorderly conduct and carrying an (unloaded) AR-15 assault rifle through a public space.
According to [[KPTV]] News, the group was organized by Aaker to aid a national fundraising campaign entitled <q>Beards for Breast Cancer</q> that was assembling a calender featuring pictures of bearding groups from around the country.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Webstaff |first1=FOX 12 |title=Burnside Bridge scare suspects: 'We are the good guys' |url=http://www.kptv.com/story/19423445/burnside-bridge-scare-suspects-we-are-the-good-guys?clienttype=printable |date=30 August 2012 |website="KPTV" |accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref> Since the Portland contingent was designated to appear alongside July, Aaker thought the resulting photo should feel especially patriotic, which led several of the beardsmen to don militaristic garb.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Staff |first1=KING |title=Bearded men on bridge cause alarm, but it's all for charity |url=https://www.king5.com/article/news/local/bearded-men-on-bridge-cause-alarm-but-its-all-for-charity/330729166 |date=30 August 2012 |website="KING-TV" |accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref> ([[KATU]] News reported that Aaker himself had on an [[NSYNC]] T-shirt.) "We are the good guys," Aaker told the station, "just a bunch of dudes walking across the bridge wearing camo getting rad."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Kalkstein |first1=Meghan |title='Just a bunch of dudes walking across the bridge wearing camo' |url=https://kval.com/news/offbeat/just-a-bunch-of-dudes-walking-across-the-bridge-wearing-camo-11-21-2015 |date=28 August 2012 |website="KVAL" |accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref>

revision.comment: Let There Be Sunshine moved page [[Khyrunnisa A]] to [[Khyrunnisa A.]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2018}} [[File:Khyrunnisa A.jpg|alt=Khyrunnisa A; Creator & author of the Butterfingers' series.|thumb|'''Nationality:''' Indian '''Genre:''' Children's Book, Realistic Fiction ]]'''Khyrunnisa A.''' is a prize-winning Indian author of children’s fiction, speaker, academic and a columnist, who created the iconic popular comic book character 'Butterfingers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://penguin.co.in/author/a-khyrunnisa/|title=Khyrunnisa A - Penguin India|work=Penguin India|access-date=2017-07-21|language=en-US}}</ref> The character first appeared in a leading children’s magazine called ''[[Tinkle]]''. Thirteen-year-old Amar Kishen, aka Butterfingers, now features in the eponymous Butterfingers series of novels and short story collections published by [[Puffin Books|Puffin]], the children’s imprint of [[Penguin Group|Penguin Books]] India, currently Penguin Random House India.
Khyrunnisa’s first three children’s novels ''Howzzat Butterfingers!'' (2010),<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/books/All-about-Butterfingers/article16191991.ece|title=All about Butterfingers|work=The Hindu|access-date=2017-07-21|language=en}}</ref> ''Goal, Butterfingers! (2012)'' and ''Clean Bowled, Butterfingers!'' ''(2015)'', were followed by two collections of short stories, ''The Misadventures of Butterfingers (2016'') and ''Run, It's Butterfingers Again!'' (2017). All the Butterfingers books were launched by [[Shashi Tharoor|Shashi Tharoor, Member of Parliament]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Thiruvananthapuram/thumbs-up-for-indian-writing/article18476520.ece|title=Thumbs up for Indian writing|work=The Hindu|access-date=2017-07-21|language=en}}</ref>
A book of her prize-winning stories, ''Lost in Ooty and Other Adventure Stories'', was brought out by Unisun Publications in 2010. Some of her stories for children and for adults have appeared in anthologies published by Puffin, Children’s Book Trust, Talking Cub and Unisun Publications. She writes stories regularly for the children’s magazine, ''Dimdima'', a Bhavan’s publication.
‘Butterfingers,’ Khyrunnisa’s entry for the Annual All India Tinkle Short story competition for adult writers of children’s fiction in 1996, won her the second prize.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/packing-a-punch/article7976594.ece|title=Packing a punch|work=The Hindu|access-date=2017-07-21|language=en}}</ref> She went on to win the first prize at the competition for the next seven consecutive years – from 1997-2003. In 2007, she won the prestigious Unisun Children’s Fiction Award. She also has five Children’s Book Trust prizes to her credit.
== Personal life == Khyrunnisa’s parents, A.R. Bijli and Ayesha Bijli, settled down in Trivandrum as her father, a post master, believed that Trivandrum was the best place to provide his eight children, seven of whom were girls, with good education.
She continues to reside in Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala, with her husband P. Vijaya Kumar, a former professor of English and the grandson of Mahakavi Kumaran Asan, who was one of the triumvirate poets of Kerala,a philosopher, a social reformer and a disciple of Sree Narayana Guru.They have one son, Amar Vijaykumar, an engineer, who is married to Arpitha Sridhara. The two are currently working in the USA.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.yentha.com/news/view/4/LITERATURE-Author-Profile-Khyrunnisa-A|title=LITERATURE: Author Profile - Khyrunnisa A - Trivandrum News {{!}} Yentha.com|last=yentha.com|website=www.yentha.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/go-butter-go/article18387112.ece|title=Go, Butter, go!|work=The Hindu|access-date=2017-07-21|language=en}}</ref>
== Education == Khyrunnisa did her schooling in [[Holy Angel's Convent Trivandrum]], and her undergraduate studies in All Saints College and postgraduate as well as M Phil. in University College, Trivandrum. She was awarded the 3rd rank for BA English Literature in [[University of Kerala|Kerala University]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.yentha.com/news/view/4/LITERATURE-Author-Profile-Khyrunnisa-A|title=LITERATURE: Author Profile - Khyrunnisa A - Trivandrum News|website=www.yentha.com|language=en|access-date=2017-06-28}}</ref>
== Career == Khyrunnisa worked as Associate Professor of English at All Saints’ College, Thiruvananthapuram. She was appointed Management Trainee in Punjab National Bank and worked there for two years before resigning to take up a teaching job at All Saints’ College.
She was a columnist for ''The New Indian Express'', writing on classics and well known works of fiction. She has freelanced for publications like ''Outlook Traveller, Manorama Year Book'' and ''Kerala Calling'', among others. She has an ongoing fortnightly column, ''Inside View,'' in ''The Hindu MetroPlus''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.yentha.com/news/view/4/LITERATURE-Author-Profile-Khyrunnisa-A|title=LITERATURE: Author Profile - Khyrunnisa A - Trivandrum News {{!}} Yentha.com|last=yentha.com|website=www.yentha.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-21}}</ref>
== Butterfingers == The Butterfinger series revolves around the hilarious escapades of thirteen-year-old Amar Kishen, a class VIII student of the fictitious Green Park Higher Secondary School. Amar’s slip-grip methods and his clumsy antics earned him the nickname Butterfingers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/interview-with-khyrunnisa-a-on-clean-bowled-butterfingers/article7350130.ece|title=For the kid within|work=The Hindu|access-date=2017-07-21|language=en}}</ref>
Butterfingers, named after Khyrunnisa’s son, Amar, first appeared in 2006 in [[Tinkle]], a popular fortnightly Indian children's magazine, as a regular comic-strip character. The illustrations were by Abhijeet Kini, the Mumbai based illustrator and graphic artist.
The popular Butterfingers series, published by Puffin, began with the novel, ''Howzzat Butterfingers!'' , In 2010.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/books/All-about-Butterfingers/article16191991.ece|title=All about Butterfingers|work=The Hindu|access-date=2017-07-21|language=en}}</ref> This humorous cricket-based book was followed in 2012 by ''Goal, Butterfingers!''<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/packing-a-punch/article7976594.ece|title=Packing a punch|work=The Hindu|access-date=2017-07-21|language=en}}</ref>'','' a rollicking football-based adventure novel which also includes a socially relevant environmental theme.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.yentha.com/news/view/4/LITERATURE-Author-Profile-Khyrunnisa-A|title=LITERATURE: Author Profile - Khyrunnisa A - Trivandrum News {{!}} Yentha.com|last=yentha.com|website=www.yentha.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-21}}</ref> The third in the series, ''‘Clean Bowled, Butterfingers!'' was published in 2015 and is another cricket-based novel with a hilariously farcical plot in which Amar and his friends invent a variation of cricket called ‘Crack It’ when the school’s cricket gear gets stolen. This game, played without cricket bats and balls, has its own absurd rules and generates immense fun.
''The Misadventures of Butterfingers'', the fourth book in the series, came out in 2016 and is a collection of short stories. It was followed by another collection of delightful short stories'', Run! It’s Butterfingers Again!''<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/go-butter-go/article18387112.ece|title=Go, Butter, go!|work=The Hindu|access-date=2017-07-21|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Thiruvananthapuram/thumbs-up-for-indian-writing/article18476520.ece|title=Thumbs up for Indian writing|work=The Hindu|access-date=2017-07-21|language=en}}</ref> in 2017.
The books have received praise from different quarters. The late [[Mansoor Ali Khan Pataudi|Mansur Ali Khan Pataudi]], former Indian cricket captain and legend, wrote of ''Howzzat Butterfingers!'': ‘What great fun! It brings back memories of my prep school days.’ The ace cricketer [[V. V. S. Laxman|V.V.S. Laxman]] described ''Clean Bowled Butterfingers'' as an ‘exuberant mix of school, cricket and fun.’ [[Shashi Tharoor]], writer, MP and diplomat, complimented Khyrunnisa ‘not just for creating Butterfingers, but for enriching Indian writing with world-class children’s literature.’
== Bibliography ==
=== Butterfingers === * ''Howzzat Butterfingers!'' (2010) * ''Goal, Butterfingers!'' (2012) * ''Clean Bowled, Butterfingers!''(2015) * ''The Misadventures of Butterfingers'' (2016). * ''Run, It's Butterfingers Again!'' (2017)
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.khyrunnisa.com Official Website] {{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:A, Khyrunnisa}} [[Category:Indian women children's writers]] [[Category:Indian children's writers]] [[Category:Women writers from Kerala]] [[Category:21st-century Indian women writers]] [[Category:University of Kerala alumni]] [[Category:Living people]]
